item.title: Cloud Hosting vs VPS
item.description:
Virtual Private Servers (VPS) offer a hosting solution for websites that have outgrown shared hosting but aren’t ready for the cost and responsibility of a fully dedicated server. However, a new option allows for flexible scaling and a pay-as-you-go model: cloud server hosting.

Discussions about cloud computing versus managing your own data center are becoming increasingly common. However, many companies haven’t reached the stage where investing in a complete in-house data center is necessary. They haven’t even considered setting up a server rack for web hosting, email, and other services. This is because outsourcing these tasks to hosting providers has become highly appealing.

Small businesses, such as those operated by freelancers, small retailers, and design studios, often start with template-based websites and hosting provided by local web services companies. As they expand beyond the basic “brochure” website or desire more control over their design and hosting, they often transition to budget-friendly hosting services found online. With hosting plans costing less than $4 per month, there’s little motivation to handle everything themselves.

How can companies offer such inexpensive hosting while remaining profitable? These low-cost plans fall under the category of shared hosting. While the control panel might give the impression of having a dedicated server, the reality is quite different. Dozens, or even hundreds, of other websites might share the same server without your knowledge. The only indication of shared resources might be occasional slowdowns. If your resource usage becomes excessive, the hosting provider might suggest upgrading to a virtual private server.

What exactly is a virtual private server? It bridges the gap between shared hosting and a dedicated server. A dedicated server provides complete control over a physical machine with its processor, memory, and storage. However, this also means bearing the cost and responsibility of managing a potentially underutilized resource. Conversely, needing more resources would require upgrading to a larger dedicated server or a cluster of servers, which can quickly become expensive.

VPS hosting utilizes virtualization software. A single physical server is divided into multiple virtual servers, each functioning like a standalone physical server. Only you and the hosting service are aware that it’s a virtual server, not a dedicated one. This shared infrastructure significantly reduces costs.

Virtual private servers offer increased resources and full root access, enabling software installation and customization. However, limitations remain due to sharing a physical machine and the challenges of adapting to changing resource requirements.

This is where cloud hosting comes in. The principle behind cloud computing is a vast pool of resources, including processors, RAM, hard drives, and bandwidth, managed by a provider. Instead of selling a fixed portion, access to this pool is leased. Similar virtualization principles as VPS hosting apply, but the resource pool is practically limitless. This allows for effortless scaling to meet current needs and easy adjustments as those needs change.

Cloud hosting servers provide choices of Linux or Windows operating systems, guaranteed CPU cycles, RAM, and hard disk space, hardware redundancy for reliability, full root/administrative access, a dedicated IP address, automatic nightly data backups, and compatibility with popular control panels like cPanel and WHM. Payment is based on hourly usage, without commitments, contracts, or setup fees. If servers are no longer needed, they can be canceled without penalty.

So, which hosting solution best suits your company? It’s recommended that organizations compare VPS, collocated private servers, and cloud hosting options, considering both pricing and features, to determine the optimal choice.

item.title: The DAG.exe in GP 2015 crashes due to the inability to load the type 'Microsoft.Dynamics.GP.BusinessObjects.Payroll.Timecard'.
item.description:
The Dynamics GP Visual Studio Tools “Dictionary Assembly Generator” (dag.exe) is a tool that I was aware of but hadn’t needed until a recent project. This project required me to access custom fields in modified GP windows.

I installed the VS Tools SDK on my GP 2015 server and ran the DAG. However, the DAG would crash during the “Generating IL code” step.

Even after upgrading to the latest hotfix, the issue persisted. My next attempt was to try the RTM version of the VS Tools SDK and GP 2015.

While searching for a solution, I came across forum posts describing a similar problem. The solution involved copying specific DLL files from the GP or AddIns directory to the VS Tools SDK folder. Based on these posts and advice from David Musgrave, I tried copying the BusinessObjects.dll file.

Through trial and error, I discovered that copying three specific DLL files from my GP 2015 folder to the VS Tools SDK folder resolved the DAG crash:

  • Microsoft.Dynamics.GP.BusinessObjects.dll
  • Microsoft.Dynamics.GP.ManagementReporterServices.dll
  • Microsoft.Dynamics.GP.Svc.Application.dll

Although the DAG no longer crashed, it would stall at 99% during the “Creating Application.MicrosoftDynamicsGp.dll” step. However, it eventually completed after a few minutes.

Hopefully, this solution proves helpful to others encountering similar issues with the DAG.

item.title: Resolve problems with Dynamics GP scaling and font size on high DPI screens.
item.description:
This blog has a new home at https://blog.steveendow.com/. Future posts will be published there.

Update: For those experiencing Remote Desktop difficulties with high DPI screens, Nathan Hayden from BKD has a helpful workaround available at: http://dynamicsinsights.com/2018/10/05/remote-desktop-high-dpi-dynamics-gp/

Modern Windows laptops and desktops with high-resolution or 4K displays often encounter display issues with some software. These “high DPI” screens can make text appear minuscule at full resolution. To counteract this, Windows uses “scaling” to enlarge text and graphics for readability and usability. While the technical aspects are complex, the goal is straightforward: making the system functional.

Windows 10 typically suggests a 200% scaling level for optimal viewing on high DPI displays. However, a 175% scaling might be preferable for maximizing screen real estate.

Scaling is generally effective, and many applications function seamlessly. Issues become apparent when an application isn’t designed to be “high DPI aware” or compatible. In such cases, display elements appear distorted, as exemplified by SugarSync in the example below.

While inconvenient, these inconsistencies are manageable. Dynamics GP 2015 initially seemed to display correctly on a Surface Pro 4. However, recent usage revealed an odd mix of font sizes, a problem also encountered by a colleague.

The menu fonts appear oversized while the left pane text is too small. SQL Server Management Studio 2014 exhibits similar issues on high DPI displays. A search for a solution led to this insightful post:

http://www.sqlservercentral.com/blogs/spaghettidba/2015/10/14/ssms-in-high-dpi-displays-how-to-stop-the-madness/

The author’s grasp of Windows’ high DPI settings led to a clever fix: modifying the scaling method for specific applications using a manifest file. While the technical details remain unclear, the solution proved effective. Importing a registry key and saving the Ssms.exe.manifest file resolved the display issues in SSMS 2014.

Although bitmap scaling at 175% might result in a slightly blurry display, it greatly enhances usability. Adjusting the scaling to 150% or 200% could help if the blurriness is bothersome.

Encouraged by the success with SSMS, the question arose: Could this method work for Dynamics GP?

(Full credit for this solution goes to Gianluca Sartori and his article)

Creating a Dynamics.exe.manifest file yielded impressive results. Dynamics GP launched and displayed correctly, without any font size discrepancies.

Capitalizing on this success, a manifest file was created for SugarSync, successfully resolving its scaling issues. The existing SugarSync manifest file was edited to incorporate the additional settings from the SSMS 2014 example.

While the specific settings within the manifest file remain a mystery, its versatility is apparent, having been successfully applied across three different applications.

Those interested in attempting this fix are advised to proceed cautiously. If you lack experience with registry editing or troubleshooting potential system errors, seek assistance from an expert.

Save the following text as a file named “Scaling.reg”:

Windows Registry Editor Version 5.00
[HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\SideBySide]
“PreferExternalManifest”=dword:00000001

Double-click the created “reg” file to import it into the Windows registry on the machine running Dynamics GP.

Next, save the following text as a file named “Dynamics.exe.manifest”:

 
   
   
 

 
   
   
 

 
   
     
   
 

 
    false
 

Place the newly created Dynamics.exe.manifest file in the same directory as the Dynamics.exe file within the GP application folder.

Testing this solution to see if it resolves the small font issues in various GP scenarios would be beneficial. Feedback on its effectiveness is welcomed.

UPDATE: It appears that GP 2013 and GP 2015 have different scaling behaviors. GP 2013 exhibits a unique set of font size issues, displaying extremely small window fonts. The Dynamics.exe.manifest file corrected these issues as well.

After implementing the manifest file:

The difference is remarkable.

item.title: Changes have been made to the User Setup window in GP 2013 R2.
item.description:
By Steve Endow

After installing GP 2013 R2, a few changes and new features are noticeable. One notable difference is the redesigned User Setup window.

GP 2013 SP2:

GP 2013 R2:

The R2 window features the noticeable ribbon at the top, a standard change in R2. Additionally, the User Setup window incorporates a few key additions.

User Type: This option, offering Full or Limited access, dictates user permissions. A Limited user is restricted to inquiries and reports. Notably, users with the POWERUSER role cannot be changed from Full to Limited access. This restriction applies to the “sa” and “DYNSA” logins as well.

Web client user only: This option designates the user specifically for the web client. They will then use their Windows account credentials instead of a SQL login.

The window now has two tabs: one for SQL Server Account information and the other for specifying a Windows Account for web client users.

Finally, there is a Home Page Role field, which, according to the help file:

“Assign[s] the user to a user role. The user role determines the content that is displayed on a user’s home page by default.”

This field is currently disabled in the current installation. It is unclear if this is due to missing configuration settings or a future feature.

item.title: Do Dynamics GP upgrades still require a test environment?
item.description:
Steve Endow, a Microsoft MVP for Dynamics GP, discusses the necessity of a test environment for “typical” Dynamics GP upgrades. He observes that while some customers have complex setups requiring thorough testing, many others have simpler environments where upgrading directly in production might be feasible.

Endow acknowledges that GP upgrades in the past were often complicated, necessitating a separate test server. However, he notes that Microsoft’s acquisition of Dynamics GP led to a streamlined and more reliable upgrade process. This leads him to question whether a separate test environment and a full test upgrade are still essential, provided appropriate backups and a solid rollback plan are in place.

He further inquires about specific factors that might make a test environment more critical, such as the use of third-party modules, customizations, integrations, the web client, on-premise versus hosted environments, and the volume of data.

In an update, Endow highlights a point made by Tim Wappat on Twitter: the use of virtual machines for running GP allows for easy backups and cloning, simplifying rollback procedures and the creation of test environments, thereby minimizing the administrative overhead associated with them.

item.title: VoIP Without The Internet
item.description:
Voice over Internet Protocol (VoIP) emerged as an alternative telephone service that utilizes existing broadband connections for both internet and phone services. This allows providers to bypass fees associated with leasing traditional copper phone lines, leading to more attractive bundled packages for customers. Theoretically, the internet’s capacity should easily accommodate low-bandwidth voice data.

However, this isn’t always the case in reality. Internet paths, much like highways, can become congested, leading to bandwidth constraints, transmission delays (latency), and dropped data packets, all of which disrupt real-time communication like phone calls.

The primary bottleneck often lies in the “first mile,” the connection between a user and their provider’s network. Shared bandwidth services like DSL and cable internet don’t guarantee consistent quality or availability, resulting in fluctuating performance and dropped calls.

While budget-conscious consumers might tolerate such inconsistencies, businesses prioritize reliable communication to avoid customer dissatisfaction and disruptions. Negative experiences with VoIP have led some businesses to avoid internet-based phone systems entirely, while others have found solutions combining the advantages of both traditional and internet phone systems.

Successful businesses often achieve this by limiting their internet usage to non-time-sensitive tasks like web browsing, email, and data exchange. This doesn’t necessitate outdated phone systems and analog lines. There are two primary methods to benefit from VoIP without compromising quality:

  1. Hybrid PBX Systems: These systems utilize IP-based phones and switches within a company’s internal network, allowing for the use of a single Ethernet LAN for both data and voice communication. This requires careful network design to ensure smooth voice data transmission but eliminates the need for separate phone lines and their associated maintenance costs. External communication is then handled via traditional phone lines connected to the IP PBX.

  2. SIP Trunking: This involves a dedicated line connecting a company’s IP PBX directly to their VoIP provider. This dedicated line, often shared with internet data, ensures voice data quality by bypassing the public internet and connecting directly to the public telephone network via the provider. This guarantees consistent bandwidth availability and avoids competition with other internet users.

Both approaches prioritize quality and control by either connecting directly to the public phone network on-site or through a dedicated connection to the provider. This avoids the unpredictable nature of the public internet.

If your business aims to upgrade its phone system without compromising reliability, our consultants can present tailored solutions that address your needs while offering cost-saving opportunities. Share your requirements with us at EnterpriseVoIP.com.

item.title: Identifying SQL Server Users without a Corresponding Login
item.description:
Let’s imagine two situations: First, you set up a test Dynamics GP server for a client by installing SQL Server and Dynamics GP, then restoring database copies. Second, a client’s Dynamics GP SQL server crashes, you rebuild it, and restore databases from backups.

Both scenarios present a common problem: restoring a database from one SQL Server to another doesn’t transfer the associated SQL Server logins.

Scenario 1 offers a solution: a “Capture Logins” script (KB 878449) efficiently transfers SQL logins to the new server.

However, Scenario 2 becomes trickier if this script isn’t regularly used. You’re left with a fresh SQL Server lacking logins, and databases containing unconnected users.

This inconvenience can be addressed by a system stored procedure encountered while studying for the SQL 2008 exam:

sp_change_users_login @Action='Report';

This procedure, proving useful beyond exam preparation, identifies orphaned users. In a real-world scenario where a rebuilt SQL server required login reconstruction, this command efficiently listed orphaned users.

While comparing SQL logins and database users is possible, this command offers a simpler approach. Security-conscious clients may also find it valuable for identifying and removing orphaned users to maintain database integrity.

This highlights a valuable, practical SQL exam takeaway applicable to Dynamics GP environments.

item.title: Beogram 4000: A New Arrival From Massachusetts - First Look
item.description:
A Beogram 4000 turntable arrived from a Massachusetts customer for a complete restoration. Thankfully, it was properly packaged and arrived without damage.

The turntable’s dust cover shows typical signs of use, but it will be replaced with a new one. The aluminum surfaces are in good shape overall.

However, there are some minor flaws. The keypad has a corner ding, suggesting it might have come loose during past transportation. Additionally, there are small scratches on the aluminum, possibly from the keypad moving around.

While the arm cover has some scuffs, the lettering is well-preserved, which is a positive sign. The plinth is in excellent condition, with sharp, undamaged corners.

Internally, the turntable appears to be mostly original, showing few signs of previous repairs. This is encouraging for the restoration process. The red carriage position marker is also in good condition.

As expected, the solenoid-actuated switch terminals show oxidation and signs of past attempts to fix them. These terminals will be cleaned, straightened, and plated with nickel and gold for long-term durability.

Initial testing showed promising results. The carriage moved correctly, the solenoid activated at the LP setdown point, and the strobe light functioned properly.

In conclusion, this Beogram 4000 restoration appears to be straightforward. The turntable is expected to be fully restored to its original appearance and functionality. Updates will follow as the process progresses.

item.title: SQL script for verifying Dynamics GP GL batch control totals
item.description:
A customer encountered a bug in their Dynamics GP integration that caused discrepancies between the actual number of imported GL transactions and the batch control totals. To identify these discrepancies, a SQL query was created to compare the number of GL transactions and JE totals with the batch control totals stored in SY00500.

The query utilizes a Common Table Expression (CTE) to efficiently calculate and compare the data. This approach helps pinpoint differences between the expected transaction count and total amount against the recorded batch control totals.

The results are displayed in a table format, highlighting any discrepancies between the transaction count or total amount. These discrepancies are flagged in the “CountDiff” and “AmountDiff” columns.

The next step involves developing a SQL script to rectify the incorrect control totals within SY00500.

item.title: Upgrade Your Business Image
item.description:
Your image as a business professional is largely controlled by your company when you work for a large corporation. However, as a small business owner, independent sales agent, or consultant, you are responsible for managing your own image. One important aspect of this is your business card.

The design and printing of your business card contribute to a polished and professional look, but an unprofessional email address can quickly ruin that impression. Using a generic free email address might be acceptable for personal use, but for a professional, it appears amateurish. Instead, opt for an email address that uses your company’s domain name, such as yourname@yourcompany.com. This not only looks more professional but is also easier for clients to remember and associate with your business. It demonstrates that you take your business seriously. Consider using a domain name service with email forwarding if you prefer to use your personal email address for business correspondence.

A professional email address is affordable, often costing less than $10 per year for a .com, .net, or .org domain name. Ideally, your domain name should match your company name or be closely related. This registration often includes domain name forwarding for your website.

Even if your business primarily operates offline, having a website is essential. It acts as a digital brochure, providing contact information and outlining your products or services. With additional effort, your website can become an online sales platform, allowing customers to place orders outside of business hours.

While free website options exist, it’s generally best to avoid them, with a few exceptions. If you represent a company that provides agent websites, these are usually professionally designed and integrated with your agent ID. However, the URLs for these sites are often lengthy and unattractive. This is where URL forwarding is beneficial. By forwarding your purchased domain name to this website, you can direct clients to a professional-looking URL like http://yourcompany.com instead of the lengthy, default one.

Another exception to avoiding free websites is a blog. Google’s Blogger service offers a free platform where the design and tools are already in place. You only need to focus on creating content. Regularly updating your blog with industry insights or offers keeps it relevant and engaging. If time or budget constraints have prevented you from creating a website, a blog is an accessible and easy-to-manage alternative.

Finally, consider using a toll-free business number. It enhances your professional image and makes it more convenient for potential customers to contact you without incurring call charges. Services like Kall8 offer affordable toll-free numbers for a low monthly fee plus the cost of calls.

item.title: ShoreTel Connect CLOUD Goes Way Beyond VoIP
item.description:
VoIP phone systems are often viewed as a direct substitute for conventional analog business phone systems, encompassing Key Telephone and PBX systems. The transition to this modern technology eliminates the need for separate phone and computer networks and allows businesses to move their internal switching system to the cloud. Moreover, switching to IP phones unlocks a wider array of features, often referred to as Unified Communications (UC).

ShorTel, a recognized leader in business communications, is widely used by companies of all sizes. Notably, ShorTel also leads in UC with its ShorTel Connect CLOUD service.

It’s crucial to understand that ShorTel Connect CLOUD is a fully hosted and managed communications solution that removes the burden of phone system management while introducing new features such as instant messaging, video conferencing, desktop sharing, and conference calling.

Furthermore, it allows for integration with Customer Relationship Management (CRM) applications like Salesforce and NetSuite, boosting employee efficiency. Automation, a core capability of Unified Communications, presents a compelling reason to upgrade from traditional analog and VoIP systems.

Cloud-based UC offers additional efficiency advantages. Instead of upfront capital expenditures, businesses opt for a pay-as-you-go monthly billing model based on the number of users. While this might seem like an even trade-off at first, it becomes particularly beneficial when scaling up or down operations. Adding new employees simply requires adding more users to the existing system without significant capital investments in a new PBX mainframe. Similarly, during economic downturns, resources can be easily adjusted to align with a smaller organizational structure.

These arguments are analogous to those used for cloud computing, and for a valid reason: the cloud functions similarly regardless of the hosted application. Essentially, voice communication becomes another application on the cloud, with the critical distinction that real-time audio and video streams necessitate special prioritization to ensure quality.

Reliability and security are paramount concerns with cloud-based systems. ShorTel addresses this by delivering enterprise-grade performance backed by robust Service Level Agreements (SLAs) and easily accessible customer support as part of its managed service.

If your business phone system feels restrictive and you’re seeking productivity gains and cost savings through cloud-hosted Unified Communications, explore what ShoreTel Connected CLOUD can offer.

item.title: Beogram 4000: Cleaning of the Tone Arm Carriage Position Switches and a Non-Returning Carriage
item.description:
As a preliminary step in the restoration of a Beogram 4000 turntable, I chose to verify the functionality of its control system. Prior testing had shown that the arm carriage would not return to its home position when moved across the platter without a record in place. Instead, it would travel to the center of the platter and stop. Ideally, the carriage should trigger the End Switch (ES) at this point and subsequently return to its home position on the right, turning off the turntable.

My initial focus was to ensure the proper operation of the carriage position switches, considering their critical role in the smooth functioning of this model. While not overly complex, I felt a video demonstration of the process would be beneficial to fellow enthusiasts working on this elegant design.

Despite cleaning the switches, the carriage run issue persisted. Upon closer examination, it became apparent that the spring responsible for activating the ES switch was not fully engaging. I removed the spring carrier again and slightly bent the spring downwards to increase the switch travel. This adjustment resolved the problem, enabling the carriage to return to its home position when moved across an empty platter.

However, further testing revealed a potential issue where the carriage could be manually positioned in a way that would not trigger the ES. This occurred when using the left arrow on the keypad to move the carriage beyond the ES activation point, seemingly overriding the ES function. As a result, the ES would release, preventing the carriage from returning when the arrow key was released.

To address this, I repositioned the ES activation spring slightly to the right on the carrier plate. This adjustment allows the carriage to reach its physical endpoint using the arrow key without moving beyond the ES switch’s activation zone.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): New Gold Plated RCA Plugs
item.description:
Over time, many Beogram devices have developed corroded DIN or RCA plugs. It’s a good idea to replace these old connectors with new, gold-plated ones. This specific Beogram 4002 (5513) came with RCA connectors.

I typically use large, modern, high-quality metal plugs for replacements. However, this project had a unique requirement: the Beogram needed to connect to a Beolab 5000. The Beolab 5000 has a compact compartment for its connectors, which creates limitations on plug size.

I chose gold-plated, all-metal Rean plugs that were short enough to fit the Beolab’s compartment. However, these plugs, like many others, have oversized cable exits. While this might accommodate the recent trend of using very thick cables, I find this excessive and prefer a cleaner look. To address this, I designed small 3D-printed inserts that would create a more streamlined appearance and provide a way to color-code the plugs.

Here’s a photo of the soldered plugs:

And here’s the final assembly:

The result is aesthetically pleasing. Here’s how the plugs look when connected to my Beolab 5000:

It’s a tight fit, but there’s still enough space to manage the cables. The last step for this Beogram restoration is to refinish the hood, which has some noticeable scratches.

item.title: Should User Account Control be disabled?
item.description:
Increasingly, as clients transition to Windows 7 or Vista, user account control issues are becoming more prevalent in Dynamics GP support, particularly with Dynamics GP Utilities. Users frequently encounter BCP utility errors after successfully launching utilities and logging in.

A quick fix is to launch Dynamics GP Utilities as an administrator. While this is straightforward, I’ve observed a concerning trend of simply recommending the disabling of user account control altogether. This approach raises concerns for me.

I strive for respect when collaborating with client IT support, acknowledging they have priorities beyond Dynamics GP. Disabling user account control feels like an IT decision, not one for a Dynamics GP consultant like myself. I can offer my perspective, but taking action blurs the lines of responsibility.

Do you share this view? Is my reaction disproportionate to a minor annoyance? It’s akin to altering permissions on shared or local drives without direct IT collaboration—something I’m hesitant to do. Am I overreacting?

I welcome your perspectives. Let me know if you consider me overly cautious or reasonable.

item.title: Beocord 5000 (4716/4715): Removing the Drive Mechanism
item.description:
Note: This post documents an outdated method. There’s a simpler way to remove the drive that doesn’t involve lifting the Pre-Amplifier board or disconnecting the solenoid linkage. See my later post for the updated procedure.

Following advice from ‘chartz’ and ‘sonavor’ on Beoworld.org (link to thread), I began replacing the belts in my Beocord 5000 (4716), which had become loose and stretched over time.

The first step is removing the drive mechanism. This involves lifting the left-side board to access the solenoid linkage. As ‘chartz’ recommended, I secured the operating panel to the enclosure’s bottom using three screws in reverse orientation. This clever trick prevents damaging the wires while working with the exposed components. Here’s a picture:

Next, I flipped up the left-side board. This board is secured by two screws: one in the back right corner and another beneath the enclosure next to the red DIN socket. With the screws removed, I carefully shifted the board to the right, disengaging it from the two brackets.

Conveniently, there are two upward-facing slots on the brackets where the board can be secured in an upright position. I recommend covering the plexiglass cover with a cloth to prevent scratches, a precaution I hadn’t taken in the following picture as I was still learning:

With that done, it was time to extract the drive.

First, I removed the solenoid linkage:

This required removing the retaining ring from its pivot shaft. I used a retaining ring tool, but it was tricky as the ring sits flush. By gently prying the ring open with the tool and wedging a small screwdriver between the ring and the linkage, I was able to raise the ring enough to get a better grip and remove it.

With the ring removed, the linkage could be rotated 90 degrees and taken out:

The next step was to disconnect the head plug, ensuring the deck was unplugged to avoid magnetizing the heads. This precaution was advised on a barely visible warning label inside the operating panel - a classic example of how not to design warnings.

Following that, I desoldered the solenoid connections:

The drive is secured at the front by two screws that go up through the enclosure’s bottom into the solenoid bracket. Here’s a view from under the enclosure:

I loosened these screws to allow the drive to slide forward.

Unlike the front, the drive’s rear isn’t secured with a screw. Instead, a bracket on the drive slots into the enclosure. By sliding the drive forward, it can be lifted out.

The final step involved disconnecting the large wire connector at the back of the drive:

This connector was quite firmly seated, and I had to carefully pry it loose with a small screwdriver before pulling it downwards. I realized then that removing the plexiglass cover would have made this easier. Finally, it came loose, and the drive was free.

Here’s a picture of the removed drive:

And the enclosure without it:

That concludes today’s work. Next time, I’ll begin disassembling the drive mechanism to access the belts.

item.title: Is Metro Ethernet Available?
item.description:
When your company needs more bandwidth, you might wonder about your options. Metro Ethernet is a popular choice, often providing more bandwidth for less money than traditional telecommunications services. But is it available in your area?

You can easily check availability using an Ethernet service finder to view a map of “lit” buildings nearby. A lit building has active fiber optic service, meaning the fiber optic cables are installed and operational with active laser light. In contrast, dark fiber refers to installed but inactive fiber optic cabling.

Lit buildings offer quick and easy access to fiber optic service. The infrastructure, like digging trenches and installing fiber cables, is already in place. Connecting you to the vast bandwidth available through fiber is a relatively simple process.

If your business is located in or can relocate to a lit building, you’re almost guaranteed access to Metro Ethernet at a competitive price. Sharing a high-bandwidth connection with other tenants presents an opportunity for even lower costs and high-volume usage. But what if your building isn’t currently serviced by fiber optics? Can you still get Metro Ethernet?

There’s a good chance you can. If a neighboring building has fiber, extending that service to your location is usually straightforward. Most of the heavy lifting, like laying fiber from the carrier’s Point of Presence (POP) to the building’s telecom room, is already done. Extending the fiber next door is a relatively minor task. In fact, you might even get this service for little to no cost if you commit to a reasonable bandwidth level.

What happens if there’s no fiber optic infrastructure in your vicinity? That scenario is trickier, depending on your location and bandwidth requirements. You might be surprised to learn that Ethernet operates on both twisted pair copper telephone cables and fiber. Not every business needs Gbps data speeds. Popular Metro Ethernet services offering 3 Mbps and 10 Mbps are easily delivered through existing copper cable infrastructure. This means you can be miles away from the nearest POP and still have access to Ethernet over Copper. While speeds up to 45 Mbps are possible, they necessitate a closer carrier POP for those higher bandwidths.

Is Metro Ethernet available in remote areas? It’s unlikely, as the “Metro” designation suggests. However, you might have options like EoDS1 (Ethernet over DS1), which utilizes T1 lines to provide Ethernet service. Ordering a single or multiple bonded T1 lines, depending on your bandwidth needs, is also a possibility regardless of your location.

To determine if Metro Ethernet is an option for your business, enter your business address (residential addresses are not applicable) into the Shop For Ethernet WAN Search box. The resulting map reveals the proximity of lit buildings to your location. Telarus consultants can then provide you with availability and pricing for Ethernet and other telecom services. You might find your location qualifies for a wider array of services and lower prices than you anticipated.

item.title: Business Telephone Systems Hosted VoIP Advantages
item.description:
Businesses of all sizes have various choices for their telephone systems. Small businesses can buy systems from local stores, while medium-sized businesses often work with contractors for key telephone systems or small PBXs. Larger companies may have internal teams that handle complex telephone systems. Nowadays, hosted VoIP is a cost-effective option for companies of all sizes.

How can one solution meet the needs of different-sized businesses affordably? It’s not a one-size-fits-all solution but a scalable technology adaptable to different demands—hosted VoIP, also known as hosted PBX or cloud telephone systems.

The cloud metaphor illustrates its nature. It involves using a large data center designed for business telephony for multiple clients. Its cloud service characteristics include significant scalable capacity and virtualization, ensuring client isolation. Billing follows a pay-as-you-go cloud model. The service provider invests in infrastructure, operation, and maintenance, while clients pay monthly per user.

Hosted VoIP usually offers telephone services comparable to advanced PBX systems. It includes call switching, in-house calls, local calls, and domestic long distance for a single price. International calls are billed separately, like traditional calling plans.

One benefit of hosted solutions is connecting multiple business locations. This setup helps avoid toll charges for interoffice calls. However, it involves network convergence and running SIP trunks between PBX systems. By bypassing traditional telephone companies, you become your own provider within your company locations.

Hosted VoIP providers manage a virtual PBX cloud. Each location connects to this cloud through your network. The cloud acts as a central hub, regardless of the handset’s physical location. These network devices can connect for conference calls.

Hosted VoIP now allows sharing external lines across locations. Internal calls stay within the network (“on-net”), while external calls require PSTN (Public Switched Telephone Network). Traditionally, each location had a PBX with dedicated outside lines, resulting in potential line availability issues. With a hosted solution, PSTN trunks reside in the cloud, accessible from any location, optimizing usage. Not all providers offer this, so inquire about this cost-saving feature if needed.

We’ve established that hosted VoIP offers advantages like scalability, pay-as-you-go pricing, no upfront investment, and no maintenance. It also connects multiple locations with advanced PBX features. Many providers integrate mobile phones for easy access. Some even include new desk phones in their service plans.

Could hosted VoIP be your next phone system? Explore pricing and features for different business telephone systems with hosted VoIP and choose what suits your company’s size.

item.title: What is the purpose of using the system password in Dynamics GP?
item.description:
A client recently brought up the Dynamics GP System Password, a feature I find comparable to User Classes – widely used in the past but less common in modern implementations. For those unfamiliar, the System Password in Dynamics GP (found under Administration Page > Setup > System Password) safeguards all system menus (Setup, Cards, Reports, etc.) with a password. This means users need to enter the password to access these windows, even if they technically have permission.

This feature was particularly beneficial in older Dynamics GP versions where security was optimistic, granting all users initial access to all windows. Implementing the System Password provided a quick security layer for these settings. However, its usefulness has diminished over time due to several factors:

  1. While the System menu houses critical windows, many equally important and potentially vulnerable windows reside within module-level setups, routines, and utilities. A comprehensive security setup is crucial for complete system protection.
  2. The System Password offers an all-or-nothing approach. If a user only requires access to specific windows, like exchange tables or Smartlist options, the password acts as a barrier.
  3. The password itself is relatively easy to recover. Someone with sufficient knowledge could potentially uncover it, even without access to the setup window.

Relying solely on the System Password can create a false sense of security for administrators. While it may seem like the system’s most vital aspects are locked down, this might not be the case. Even with the introduction of pessimistic, role and task-based security in Dynamics GP (where users initially only have login access), many continue to use the System Password as a simple extra check. This practice isn’t necessarily problematic if robust security measures are in place, including control over windows accessed through security menus. However, if your security strategy doesn’t account for the points mentioned above, relying on the System Password as your primary defense is strongly discouraged.

Christina Phillips is a Microsoft Certified Trainer and Dynamics GP Certified Professional. item.title: What qualities define exceptional training?
item.description:
Over the past few weeks, I’ve been leading training sessions, including a Dynamics GP Distribution Partner Academy and a customized Forecaster training. These distinct classes got me thinking about the elements of exceptional training and what makes it truly valuable. I’d love to share my thoughts and hear yours!

  1. Relevant Content: It’s crucial for training content to align with student needs. While this can be challenging with pre-determined classes, instructors can bridge the gap by connecting content to real-world scenarios. Students, too, play a role by actively sharing their experiences and insights.

  2. Collaborative Learning: Learning becomes much more dynamic when students actively participate and share their experiences. While the instructor guides the discussion, genuine understanding blossoms when students connect and learn from each other.

  3. Practical Application: Knowing the “what” is important, but the true value lies in understanding “how” to apply knowledge in practical situations. Instructors can facilitate this by sharing their own experiences and encouraging students to do the same, extending learning beyond the classroom. I personally find it incredibly rewarding when students share their post-training successes.

  4. Full Engagement: Everyone involved - both the instructor and students - needs to be fully present and engaged for a training to be truly effective. Instructors should create an environment that welcomes diverse perspectives, while students should actively participate and contribute their unique viewpoints. A knowledgeable and well-prepared instructor who can go beyond the textbook is essential.

I’m eager to hear your perspectives on what constitutes excellent training, students, and instructors! Share your thoughts!

item.title: Managed Hosting PBX Gets You Out Of The Telephone Business
item.description:
A lot of businesses find themselves managing their own phone systems simply because they need phones to operate, even though it’s not their core business. This has become the norm, but it doesn’t have to be this way anymore.

Companies previously invested in extensive phone systems because the productivity gains from each employee having a direct line outweighed the costs. In the past, a single phone line sufficed, but with the information age, constant communication became essential, driving the need for dedicated telecom departments.

These departments manage the PBX system, essentially a smaller version of a phone company’s central office. It connects internal calls and manages external lines. This setup requires constant upkeep, including replacing faulty phones, rewiring, and managing employee changes, all adding to the cost of doing business.

The financial burden includes managing these daily changes and the capital expense of the equipment. PBX systems are costly, and upgrades can necessitate loans for significant replacements. However, there’s a more efficient alternative: hosted PBX.

Hosted PBX shifts the responsibility of managing the system to a third-party provider. This eliminates the need for on-site equipment and frees up your resources. With this setup, employees can enjoy the same, if not better, phone functionality, often with “smart” phones integrated with the computer network.

This is possible due to the widespread use of company computer networks. Phones now use the existing broadband network to transmit data packets, connecting to a service provider who manages everything remotely. This makes them more efficient and cost-effective. It’s essentially a return to “telephone as a service,” or in today’s terms, “voice as a service.”

If your company is stuck managing its phone system, it’s worth exploring managed PBX hosting solutions. You might find a better and more cost-effective option for your business needs.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Restoration of the Main PCB and Installation of a Biasing Trimmer for TR3
item.description:
After getting the Beogram 4002 (5513) operational again, I focused on fully restoring the main PCB. This involved installing a trimmer to correctly calibrate TR3, the transistor responsible for amplifying the signal from the record detection sensor. The board’s condition upon arrival is shown below:

The RPM relay and trimmers had already been replaced by the owner. I finished the restoration by replacing all electrolytic capacitors

and adding a trimmer to enable bias adjustment at the base of TR3. To make adjustments with the board powered on, the trimmer was temporarily placed on the back, as pictured here:

After adjusting the collector DC voltage to 4.0V, I fixed the trimmer to the component side:

The original design used a fixed resistor, often causing insufficient amplification due to inconsistencies in the TR3 transistor’s current gain. Adequate amplification is crucial to avoid needle damage if the turntable is accidentally started without a record in place.

Next, I improved the installation of the replacement reservoir capacitor assembly, which had been installed previously:

Moving on to installing an LED in the sensor arm…

item.title: SmartList Builder and SQL Tables/Views
item.description:
Many of you may already know this, but I encountered a problem this week deploying a SmartList Builder item. Here’s what happened:

  1. I created two SQL views based on GP and custom tables.
  2. I granted the SmartList Builder access to these views (Tools » SmartList Builder » Security » SQL Table Security).
  3. I created my SmartList (Tools » SmartList Builder » SmartList Builder).
  4. After testing, the SmartList worked correctly.
  5. I deployed the views to the client’s environment.
  6. I exported the SmartList Builder settings to an XML file.
  7. I imported the XML file into the client’s system.
  8. I granted access to the views for SmartList Builder at the client site.
  9. When trying to view the SmartList, an error appeared: “You do not have security privileges to view all of the tables used in this SmartList.”
  10. Following KB Article #967731, I configured a Security Task and Security Role to include “Smarlist Builder\Smartlist Builder Permissions\Smartlist Builder\View Smartlists with SQL Tables.”
  11. The error persisted.
  12. I granted DYNGRP SELECT permissions on both views.
  13. The error remained.
  14. I ran Grant.SQL.
  15. The error still occurred.

Frustratingly, this error affected both regular users and the ‘sa’ account. The solution? Permissions must be set before importing the XML file. While I haven’t confirmed the minimum steps, ensure steps 8, 12, and 14 are completed before importing. To be safe, I recommend steps 8, 10, 12, and 14.

After setting permissions and then importing the XML, everything worked perfectly. It seems permissions set after import aren’t fully recognized.

Happy holidays!

item.title: Users of Forecaster and Dynamics GP
item.description:
Have you ever encountered a problem where you vaguely recall a solution but can’t seem to locate the specific article or link? This happened to me recently with a client attempting to use their Dynamics GP user ID for Forecaster 7. As expected, it was unsuccessful due to GP’s encryption method when generating user IDs in SQL. This encryption prevents the same ID from functioning in Forecaster, even with proper database permissions.

I’m documenting it here for future reference. However, I commend the client for their efforts to streamline the process.

item.title: 3x3 Mbps Ethernet Doubles Your Bandwidth
item.description:
In today’s world, who couldn’t benefit from additional internet speed? Websites, software, and files continue to grow larger, but unfortunately, technology budgets haven’t kept pace. Imagine doubling your internet speed without increasing your current expenses – an appealing proposition, wouldn’t you agree?

It might sound illogical to suggest that doubling your internet speed wouldn’t cost more, especially since internet providers aren’t known for giving things away for free. The secret lies in adopting newer, more cost-effective technology instead of simply replacing your existing service with an identical one from another provider.

One way to double your internet speed with your current or a new provider, while retaining your T1 line service, is to order a second T1 line and “bond” it with your existing line. Bonding combines two lines to function as a single, faster line. A single T1 line provides 1.5 Mbps, so bonding two lines results in a speed of 3 Mbps. 

However, there are a couple of limitations. First, both T1 lines must be from the same provider, either your current one or a new one for both lines. Second, your monthly cost will double since you’re now paying for two lines. While you might find a different vendor offering lower prices for the same service, this alone likely won’t get you 3 Mbps for the price of 1.5 Mbps.

Instead of simply doubling down on T1 lines, consider switching to Ethernet over Copper. Both are dependable business-grade internet services with dedicated bandwidth. They can also be managed services, where the provider handles all the necessary equipment at your location to connect to their lines and your network. 

Another similarity between bonded T1 lines and Ethernet over Copper is that they both utilize the existing copper telephone wires already installed in your building. Although the signal types differ between T1 and Ethernet lines, they function the same way from a user’s perspective. 

The key difference lies in the cost. Ethernet over Copper, being a newer technology, utilizes the bandwidth capacity of copper lines more effectively. As a result, its pricing is very competitive, currently about half the cost of two bonded T1 lines. This means you could obtain a 3 Mbps Ethernet over Copper service for the same price as a 1.5 Mbps T1 service. 

A few other distinctions exist as well. T1 lines can only be upgraded in increments of 1.5 Mbps per bonded line. Ethernet, on the other hand, offers more flexibility, with bandwidth options ranging from 1 Mbps up to 10 Gbps, though higher speeds necessitate fiber optic cables. However, unlike T1, Ethernet over Copper has limited availability, primarily found in larger cities and suburbs rather than rural areas.

Interested in doubling your internet speed without increasing your costs? Check pricing and availability for 3 x 3 Mbps Ethernet over Copper or other Ethernet bandwidth services to discover potential savings in your area.

item.title: IT Departments are Wearin' the Green
item.description:
Maintaining IT budgets requires more than just good fortune these days. Many companies are discovering that environmentally friendly practices can save them money. These eco-conscious choices benefit both the planet and their bottom line.

One of the first areas to examine is electricity consumption. Power usage can be deceptive because it often occurs in small, unnoticeable increments. Every desktop computer, even when idle, contributes to the overall energy use, measured in watt-hours and kilowatt-hours. While electricity costs are easily offset by profits generated from productive work, the issue arises during idle time. Even when computers are unused, they still consume power, leading to unnecessary expenses.

Many companies have adopted a policy of shutting down computers and monitors overnight and during extended periods of inactivity. This practice has been proven to generate significant savings without significantly impacting equipment lifespan. In reality, most computers become obsolete before they wear out from use. When disposing of old electronics, it’s crucial to recycle responsibly, as circuit boards and CRTs contain hazardous materials. Proper recycling prevents these toxins from polluting the environment.

Turning off equipment when not in use, ideally with a mechanical switch that cuts off standby power, offers two advantages. First, it directly reduces the device’s power consumption. Second, it minimizes heat generation. No electronic device is perfectly efficient; some energy is always lost as heat. While essential for operation, this heat can become excessive, especially in server rooms.

Server rooms, with their concentrated computing power, often require substantial cooling. As equipment density increases, so does the need for air conditioning, creating a cycle of escalating energy consumption. To address this, designers are focusing on more efficient power supplies and even exploring DC power distribution.

However, maintaining an on-site server room might not always be the most practical solution. Colocation facilities offer a compelling alternative by distributing power and environmental control costs among multiple users. Additionally, colocation often provides access to more competitive bandwidth pricing.

For businesses looking to further minimize their reliance on grid power, generating their own electricity is an option. Office buildings and factories often have large, unused roof areas suitable for solar panel installation. By feeding into the grid, these solar arrays can significantly reduce daytime power consumption, especially during peak pricing hours. Google, among other companies, has already embraced solar power to supplement its energy needs.

If you’re considering upgrading to more energy-efficient computing equipment, consider consulting a network of value-added resellers. These experts can help you find the best deals on servers and network devices that can contribute to both environmental and financial savings.

item.title: Lit Buildings Have Near Infinite Bandwidth
item.description:
By: John Shepler

When choosing a business location, consider “lit buildings” for their exceptional connectivity. These buildings are already equipped with fiber optic internet infrastructure, offering a solution to bandwidth concerns.

What Does “Lit Building” Mean?

“Lit building” signifies a building pre-wired for fiber optic internet and potentially point-to-point bandwidth services. The term “lit” references the laser beams used to transmit digital signals at high speeds through fiber optic cables.

Advantages of Fiber Lit Buildings

In today’s business landscape, seamless electronic communication is essential, from small enterprises to large corporations. If your operations depend on computers, connectivity is crucial. Even the smallest businesses require internet access for credit card processing, online orders, email communication, and website management. Operating offline can hinder business growth.

However, securing reliable internet access can be challenging when moving into a new facility. Standalone buildings or being the first tenant often means bearing the cost and effort of installing internet service, including cabling, termination equipment setup, and provider coordination.

Lit buildings eliminate these challenges because the costly and time-consuming infrastructure is already in place. Simply contract with the building’s fiber optic provider, connect your router to their termination point, and your business is online.

Services Offered in Lit Buildings

Fiber optic connections surpass traditional landlines and cable internet by offering practically limitless bandwidth. While technical limitations exist, advancements in modulation and multiplexing techniques continually increase the bandwidth capacity of a single fiber strand, with speeds of 10 Gbps readily available and 100 Gbps becoming increasingly common. For larger businesses requiring even higher bandwidth, fiber optic cables can combine hundreds of individual strands.

The services available in lit buildings are comprehensive. Ethernet over Fiber, directly compatible with most Local Area Networks (LANs), is a popular choice offering scalable bandwidth from 10 Mbps to 10 Gbps and beyond. Many providers grant users portal access for on-demand bandwidth adjustments. Traditional Synchronous Optical Networking (SONET) services like OC3 to OC48 might also be available and can be demultiplexed to provide traditional T1 line or Integrated Services Digital Network (ISDN) PRI phone service. Additionally, Session Initiation Protocol (SIP) trunking for Voice over Internet Protocol (VoIP) and dedicated cloud connections are typically standard offerings.

Why Not Opt for Fiber?

Fiber optic internet provides a transparent and future-proof bandwidth solution that effortlessly scales with business growth. The primary drawback is the cost, which can be prohibitive for small businesses and limited budgets. In such cases, business cable broadband offers a more budget-friendly option. If cable infrastructure is available at your location, you can access shared bandwidth up to 1000 Mbps at a competitive price, often without installation charges. Importantly, cable internet availability is independent of whether a building is equipped for fiber.

When considering relocation, prioritize your current and future bandwidth needs. Before committing to a lease, verify the availability of lit building fiber optic services and cable broadband.

item.title: Are Your T1 Lines Saturated?
item.description:
By: John Shepler

The perfect network connection is invisible. Whether it uses copper wires, coaxial cable, fiber optics, or wireless technology, if it impacts your network traffic, it’s not truly transparent. The more noticeable these limitations become, the more they hinder productivity, demanding your attention.

Artificial Limitations

Shared broadband services like Cable, DSL, 4G Cellular, or satellite internet, despite promising “best effort,” are inherently limited by technology and company policies. Each type has a maximum capacity, typically accessible round-the-clock, except for rare outages. However, users only get a fraction of this capacity.

Firstly, bandwidth is capped. You’re purchasing a maximum speed, not a guaranteed one. Providers control this with rate limits. Your line might support 1000 Mbps, but you’re restricted to 10, 30, or 100 Mbps, regardless of other users.

Secondly, usage limits are imposed, especially on wireless and satellite connections where bandwidth is costly. Limits like 5 or 10 GB per month severely restrict usage, and even 20 or 50 GB might be insufficient for regular business operations. Exceeding this limit can result in extra charges, disconnections, or slower speeds for the remainder of the billing cycle.

Actual Limitations

Private and dedicated internet connections usually avoid artificial limitations. These premium services ensure you’re the sole user, eliminating the need for usage policies.

However, technical limitations persist. Every technology has inherent constraints. “Unlimited” bandwidth is a myth, even on local networks. The goal is to have sufficient bandwidth to avoid reaching capacity.

T1 Line Saturation

T1 lines, offering dedicated connections between two points or to the internet, have been the business standard for decades. As the sole user, there are no usage restrictions, and the line constantly allows data transfer. You utilize and pay a fixed price for a portion or all available capacity.

T1 lines offer 1.5 Mbps bandwidth, more precisely 1.544 Mbps. However, 8 Kbps is reserved for line synchronization, leaving 1.536 Mbps for actual data – equivalent to 16.59 GB daily or nearly 500 GB monthly.

Line Saturation Problems

Your T1 line reveals its limitations when transferring large files quickly or accommodating multiple users simultaneously. With a maximum capacity of roughly 17 GB daily, transferring even 1 GB per hour becomes challenging.

Attempting to exceed this limit slows down everyone’s traffic significantly. This bottleneck hinders productivity, especially when access to information is crucial for continuing work.

The situation worsens with cloud-based phone systems (VoIP). Voice data gets stuck in the bottleneck alongside other data, causing call quality issues like garbled speech, delays, and even dropped calls.

Solutions

For occasional saturation, prioritizing traffic can be beneficial. Real-time services like calls and video conferences get top priority, followed by business applications, and finally, background tasks like backups.

Ultimately, upgrading to higher bandwidth becomes necessary. Fortunately, costs have decreased significantly. Doubling your bandwidth with a second T1 line is an option. These lines can be “bonded” to act as a single, faster connection.

Ethernet over Copper, using existing copper lines, offers speeds of 10 Mbps and beyond. For these speeds, Ethernet over Fiber becomes cost-effective, scaling from 10 to 100, 1000, and even 10,000 Mbps. These services allow you to start with a lower speed and pay less until full capacity is needed.

If your T1 lines or other connections are struggling, explore pricing and availability of higher bandwidth services for your business location.

item.title: Disable all Dynamics GP posting reports in the Fabrikam test company.
item.description:
Steve Endow

No More Clicking “Cancel”

Update: Victoria Yudin accurately pointed out that posting reports are sometimes useful or even necessary, for example, in training or when troubleshooting errors. She’s absolutely right - posting reports are definitely needed in certain situations, even in Fabrikam. I personally disabled posting reports in my testing environment because I frequently run repetitive tests on batch posting for my projects. I already know that my data, transactions, and postings are all accurate. So, in my case, I don’t need the posting reports or the dialog boxes, and I turn them off to avoid constantly clicking “Cancel.”

It’s a little disheartening to be aware of exactly how many times you have to click “Cancel” on the report dialog boxes after posting a certain Dynamics GP batch.

My desire to avoid this repetitive clicking finally outweighed my laziness in disabling the reports. I finally took 10 seconds to write a script to disable all posting reports in Fabrikam:

UPDATE TWO..SY02200 SET PRNTJRNL = 0

And that’s it. Done.

Now I need to make this a standard step in my GP installation process after creating the Fabrikam company.

Batches and posting reports…two relics of the ERP world that GP will likely never leave behind…

Ask a NetSuite consultant about their “batches” and “posting reports” if you want to see some confused faces.

item.title: What Is Toll Free?
item.description:
The term “toll free number” is widely recognized, with most people having used one. But what exactly does it mean and how do businesses acquire them?

Unlike standard phone numbers automatically assigned with landline, VoIP, or cellular services, toll free numbers require a separate process. In the US and Canada, phone numbers follow the North American Numbering Plan (NANP) format: 1-NPA-NXX-XXXX.

In this format, “1” represents the country code, NPA stands for Numbering Plan Area (area code), and the remaining digits are unique to your line. The area code often indicates a geographical location, although VoIP providers can manipulate this.

Toll free numbers utilize specific area codes called toll free prefixes. While the term “toll free” implies free calls, it actually means the calling party doesn’t incur charges for the call. The owner of the toll free number is responsible for the cost of incoming calls.

To obtain a toll free number, businesses can order them from specialized companies. There are typically two payment options: a monthly fee plus per-minute charges for incoming calls, or a fixed monthly fee regardless of call volume.

Easily recognizable by their prefixes (800, 888, 877, 866, 855), toll free numbers are not tied to specific phone lines. Instead, you assign a “ring-to” number, directing incoming calls to any phone line you choose.

The popularity of toll free numbers has led to the introduction of multiple prefixes beyond the original 800, all functioning identically.

item.title: The Hyper-V virtual machine running Server 2012 R2 is unable to start and displays an error message stating "We were unable to finish the updates.
item.description:
By Steve Endow

While attempting to set up the GP 2016 Web Client on a new Server 2012 R2 virtual machine, I encountered an error message stating “We couldn’t complete the updates. Undoing changes.” The VM became unresponsive.

After some searching, I came across a TechNet forum thread discussing similar issues with Windows 8. Unfortunately, the suggested fix of disabling Secure Boot on the VM was unsuccessful in my case.

I eventually found a blog post by Andy Parkes that offered a solution: installing roles and features directly onto a VM’s VHD file using Server Manager. This method was new to me and proved to be effective.

Following the instructions, I was able to resolve the initial issue, and the VM began applying updates. However, the update process stalled at 100%. I waited a while, but there was no indication of progress.

I decided to power down the VM, disable Secure Boot again, and restart. This time, it displayed “Undoing changes” for a few minutes before finally booting up with a “Preparing Windows” message.

Unfortunately, even after successfully booting, Windows Update still displayed a significant number of pending updates.

item.title: Cheaper Connections To The Cloud
item.description:
Businesses are often quick to celebrate the cost savings of cloud services compared to maintaining their own data centers. However, there’s a hidden cost that often catches them off guard: cloud connectivity.

The current cost of bandwidth depends on a company’s blend of LAN, MAN, and WAN traffic. Businesses with data centers located in the same building as their employees usually find most of their application traffic stays on the LAN. While a dedicated broadband internet connection is necessary for external communication, a moderate line speed can accommodate a large number of users if their usage is limited to email and web browsing.

E-commerce, however, is a different story. If customer and external user traffic dominate, a high-bandwidth connection is crucial for public-facing servers. In such cases, WAN traffic may even exceed LAN traffic.

Similarly, offsite but local data centers, even those primarily used for backup, recovery, or data mirroring, require high-bandwidth connections. This scenario often results in the majority of bandwidth being used by MAN rather than LAN or WAN.

The transition to the cloud significantly alters this dynamic. With public servers becoming rented services, bandwidth costs are absorbed into the service fee, potentially eliminating the need for a MAN connection altogether for cloud storage users. What becomes essential, however, is a significantly larger bandwidth pipe between the company’s premises and the cloud service provider.

Companies accustomed to in-house operations might be surprised by the increased cost of private line services to the cloud, potentially offsetting their anticipated savings. Conversely, companies currently burdened by high internet bandwidth costs may find relief in the cloud provider’s inclusive bandwidth to the internet. Creating a simple chart comparing LAN, MAN, and WAN bandwidth needs for both current and cloud-based setups is a worthwhile exercise.

Regardless of the resulting bandwidth mix, maximizing value for money is key. Fortunately, there are now more options than ever before, driven by competition and technological advancements.

One such advancement is Ethernet over Copper (EoC). EoC directly rivals traditional and high-bandwidth T1 lines, and in some cases, even fiber optic services.

Utilizing existing copper telephone wiring, EoC employs a more efficient modulation scheme than T1, achieving higher bandwidths. Unlike T1, EoC is distance-sensitive, requiring proximity to a telco office, making it suitable for urban and suburban areas but less so for rural locations.

EoC bandwidth options typically range from 2 to 20 Mbps, with some metropolitan areas offering services equivalent to 45 Mbps DS3. There are even providers offering 100 Mbps bandwidth over copper.

The pricing for EoC services is particularly attractive. 2-3 Mbps Ethernet service can often be acquired for the price of a T1 line, and discounts of 50% or more compared to traditional telecom services for higher bandwidth EoC are not uncommon.

Whether planning a move to the cloud or seeking to reduce current line service costs, exploring pricing and availability of EoC and other bandwidth services could reveal pleasant surprises.

item.title: Update the notes in Dynamics GP through an eConnect integration.
item.description:
Steve Endow

While I’ve worked with eConnect integrations extensively, I recently encountered a situation where I needed to update existing Dynamics GP Note records. I couldn’t recall having done this before, and online searches didn’t provide any solutions. If you know of an easier approach, please share, as I’m curious if I’ve overlooked something.

Let’s imagine your .NET eConnect integration needs to update a customer’s address and phone number, and simultaneously append an update message to the existing customer note. Seems straightforward, right?

However, using the eConnect taUpdateCreateCustomerRcd NOTETEXT field overwrites any existing customer note. Despite exploring documentation and searching for ways to programmatically update existing GP notes, including standard zDP and eConnect “ta” stored procedures, I couldn’t find any direct methods. While the SY03900 note table itself is simple, a more convenient way to update notes would be beneficial.

You could create a single SQL stored procedure, but I wanted to avoid adding another custom procedure for this client.

Another option is an eConnect Post procedure, but I find them cumbersome. They resemble custom stored procedures, which I wanted to avoid, and often need to be recreated after GP service packs or upgrades, making them easy to forget.

Anyway…

First, ensure the customer record exists in the SY03900 table. While new customer records are automatically assigned a NOTEINDX value, a corresponding record in SY03900 isn’t automatically created. Trying to update the note for customer ACME001 in SY03900 without an existing record will fail.

I created a quick SQL snippet to check for an existing Note record and create one if needed:

8
9

IF NOT EXISTS (SELECT TOP 1 NOTEINDX FROM SY03900 WHERE NOTEINDX = (SELECT NOTEINDX FROM RM00101 WHERE CUSTNMBR = 'ACME001'))

BEGIN

INSERT INTO SY03900 (NOTEINDX, DATE1, TIME1, TXTFIELD)

VALUES ((SELECT NOTEINDX FROM RM00101 WHERE CUSTNMBR = 'ACME001'), CONVERT(VARCHAR(10), GETDATE(), 101), CONVERT(VARCHAR(12), GETDATE(), 108), '')

END

Next, I adapted some excellent SQL code by Tim Wappat, who shared a script for fixing line breaks in GP note records:

1
2
3

UPDATE SY03900 SET TXTFIELD = CAST(TXTFIELD AS varchar(MAX)) + CHAR(13) + 'Text to append'

WHERE NOTEINDX = (SELECT NOTEINDX FROM RM00101 WHERE CUSTNMBR = 'ACME001')

This update script adds a new line to the note, appending new text at the end.

Using this approach, after updating the existing customer contact information in GP with eConnect, you’ll need a separate method for the note update.

This example specifically addresses updating customer notes. However, it can be adapted for vendor and other note types. With some effort, you could potentially create a more abstract solution for updating notes across different record types.

item.title: I, Router
item.description:
An interesting consequence of technological progress is the creation of fabrics capable of producing electricity simply from the wearer’s movement. This involves nanowires covered in zinc oxide that transform mechanical energy into electrical energy, illustrating the scientific principle of energy conversion.

The creator of this innovation suggests incorporating it into clothing like shirts and shoes to power devices like iPods or medical implants. Currently, the power density is 80 milliwatts per square meter of fabric, but this could increase significantly in the future, potentially reaching several watts per garment, especially with more vigorous movements.

While using this technology to charge an iPod while walking is appealing for reducing carbon emissions, imagine the possibilities of recharging hybrid cars at stoplights or even powering homes. The implications for energy independence and environmental protection are significant.

Taking this further, envision wearable integrated circuits woven into clothing, similar to electric blankets. By combining existing miniaturized wireless technology with power-generating fabric, clothing could become mobile WiFi nodes, creating a dynamic network that fluctuates with people’s movements and activities.

This mesh network could provide widespread wireless broadband coverage, addressing the power supply issues of traditional methods. The network’s strength would vary throughout the day, peaking during work and school hours and adapting as people change clothes and move about.

Within this network, individuals become walking power sources, routers, and communication hubs. Clothing could even integrate network voice features, essentially becoming “softswitches” for making calls over the Internet.

Expanding this concept, even animals could contribute to broadband coverage. Imagine large animals with their considerable surface area acting as mobile transmitters, extending network access to remote areas and underserved populations. However, the logistics of outfitting certain animals with such technology present a challenge.

item.title: EV-DO Expands In The Face of WiMAX
item.description:
The arrival of 4G technology, specifically Sprint’s nationwide WiMAX network, raises questions about the future of 3G. While WiMAX boasts speeds up to 70 Mbps, suggesting a potential shift, the reality is more nuanced.

Sprint’s commitment to a national WiMAX network, with its impressive 31-mile range and 70 Mbps bandwidth, signals a potential shift in mobile technology. Realistically, users can expect speeds around 2-4 Mbps, especially when mobile. This rivals the current leading 3G service, EV-DO.

Developed by Qualcomm, EV-DO, short for “Evolution - Data Optimized,” is a standard for CDMA cellular transmission. It provides internet access and video on demand alongside traditional voice services. Major carriers like Verizon (BroadbandAccess and VCAST) and Sprint (Amp’d Mobile) have embraced EV-DO.

EV-DO, with download speeds of 2.4 Mbps and upload speeds of 153 Kbps, is comparable to DSL, cable, and satellite internet. Users typically experience 400-700 Kbps download speeds, sufficient for multimedia messaging, email, web browsing, and video/audio downloads.

EV-DO evolved from 1xRTT, offering speeds of 60-80 Kbps. While faster than dial-up, it struggles with bandwidth-heavy applications. This evolution is crucial as 1xRTT remains prevalent on CDMA networks, with EV-DO still being deployed beyond major cities and airports.

EV-DO Rev A, a backward-compatible upgrade, boosts peak download speeds to 3.1 Mbps and upload speeds to 1.8 Mbps. It also introduces Quality of Service (QoS) support, reducing latency for applications like push-to-talk, instant messaging, and potentially VoIP, although carriers remain cautious due to existing voice services.

As Sprint and Verizon upgrade to EV-DO Rev A, the next iteration, Rev B, is on the horizon. Launching next year, Rev B enhances performance to 4.9 Mbps per channel, with up to 15 channels working concurrently for a theoretical 73.5 Mbps download and 27 Mbps upload speed. Importantly, it maintains backward compatibility with previous versions.

This similarity between Rev B’s 73.5 Mbps and WiMAX’s 70 Mbps begs the question: is 3G evolving into 4G? In a sense, yes. Verizon, lacking independent WiMAX licenses, benefits significantly from this evolution. Ultimately, this bandwidth expansion paves the way for wireless applications previously restricted by limited airlink channels.
