item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Restoration of PCBs
item.description:
Following the restoration of the arm lowering and tracking mechanisms on a Beogram 4002 turntable, the subsequent task involves refurbishing the printed circuit boards (PCBs) and replacing the reservoir capacitor.

The initial focus is on the main PCB. It was in its original state, showing signs of age and use. A detailed view highlights the RPM control section, which was particularly important for speed stability.

All electrolytic capacitors on the board were replaced with new, high-quality Japanese components rated for 105 degrees Celsius. Additionally, a new relay and a set of 25-turn, encapsulated trimmers for RPM adjustment were installed. For comparison, the old and new versions of the relay and trimmers were shown side-by-side. These upgraded components are offered to other enthusiasts interested in restoring their own Beogram turntables.

The rebuilt board, alongside the extracted components, demonstrates the extent of the refurbishment. It’s important to note that the trimmers were positioned so that their adjustment screws extended through the PCB. This allows for RPM adjustments while the board is installed, and the platter is rotating.

Next, the output PCB, which houses the output grounding relay, was rebuilt. The delay capacitor and the relay were replaced, and a switch was added to connect the system and signal grounds. This feature is beneficial when using an RCA adapter with the turntable, as it can help eliminate humming that sometimes occurs.

Finally, a new reservoir capacitor was installed. This Beogram 4002 had a dual-capacitance type, no longer available, featuring a 4000uF section and a 1000uF section. The 1000uF section is utilized only when a CD-4 board is present, which is uncommon. The 4000uF section is crucial for the Beogram’s operation. To replace this discontinued component, a two-capacitor assembly was used with a 3D-printed adapter designed to fit the original capacitor’s mounting bracket. A 20k resistor was added across the 1000uF capacitor to discharge it when the turntable is unplugged for maintenance or transportation.

The next phase of the restoration project will involve rebuilding the RPM trimmer panel and upgrading the scale illumination from traditional light bulbs to LED assemblies.

item.title: High Fiber Diet for Business Not Expensive
item.description:
With business picking up, many companies are hitting a wall – their internet connections can’t keep up with the increased data flow. The solution? A high-fiber diet for their network.

Fiber optic cables are incredibly efficient. A single strand can handle massive amounts of voice, data, and video simultaneously, far exceeding the needs of most businesses. This capacity can be further multiplied by splitting the light into different wavelengths, each carrying gigabits per second. A fiber optic connection essentially unlocks almost limitless bandwidth potential for your business.

While fiber optic communication was once prohibitively expensive, competition has significantly driven down prices. Unlike the past, where local phone companies held a monopoly, numerous providers now offer fiber optic services. Many possess their own fiber optic core networks and access networks using both fiber and copper.

Using copper, multiple twisted-pair wiring can deliver Ethernet speeds up to 45 Mbps by connecting to nearby carrier hubs. Fiber optic access is also a viable option for most city-based businesses, especially where usage justifies the installation cost. It’s becoming standard for office buildings and industrial parks to include fiber optic service as a basic utility during construction, allowing tenants to easily adjust their service level based on their needs.

What services can you get with fiber optic connections? A basic option is DS3, a digital service also used on T3 lines, offering 45 Mbps. However, DS3 uses just a fraction of a single fiber strand’s capacity. This means multiple customers can have their DS3 connections bundled on the same fiber optic line.

SONET, or Synchronous Optical NETwork, is the standard fiber optic service. Common SONET options include OC3 (155 Mbps), OC12 (622 Mbps), OC-48 (2.5 Gbps), and OC-192 (10 Gbps). While other levels exist, they are less widely available.

Many newer providers have built their networks on IP technology instead of the traditional telco standard, SONET. They offer Ethernet as a WAN service with various speed options, including 10 Mbps, 100 Mbps (Fast Ethernet), and 1000 Mbps (Gigabit Ethernet or GigE). Getting 10 Gbps Ethernet is feasible and surprisingly affordable if your business demands it, especially when time-to-market and productivity are crucial.

The cost of fiber optic services has become much more manageable. It’s common to find 100 Mbps Ethernet for a fraction of its past cost. If you require more bandwidth or haven’t explored pricing recently, get updated quotes before assuming it’s out of reach. You might be pleasantly surprised.

Discover the range of fiber optic services and their costs for your business location through our GigaPackets online resource. We provide quick and easy answers.

item.title: Additional Payroll Troubleshooting Scripts for Your Enjoyment!
item.description:
Let’s dive into more FUTA and SUTA insights. These scripts can help pinpoint inconsistencies in your configuration and uncover potential reasons for incorrect FUTA and SUTA wage calculations. You can run each script against your company database to find records with potential problems.

– This script finds employees without a default SUTA state (accessible in the system through Cards»Payroll»Employee)

select EMPLOYID as EmployeeID from UPR00100 where SUTASTAT=''

– This script identifies employee pay code records (accessible in the system through Cards»Payroll»Pay Code) that aren’t flagged for FUTA or SUTA, or lack a SUTA state despite the pay code setup (accessible in the system through Setup»Payroll»Pay Code) requiring it.

select UPR00400.EMPLOYID as EmployeeID, UPR00400.PAYRCORD as PayCode, UPR00400.SBJTFUTA as SubjectToFUTA, UPR00400.SBJTSUTA as SubjectToSUTA, UPR00400.SUTASTAT as SUTAState from UPR00400 inner join UPR40600 on UPR00400.PAYRCORD=UPR40600.PAYRCORD WHERE (UPR00400.SBJTFUTA=0 AND UPR40600.SBJTFUTA=1) OR (UPR00400.SBJTSUTA=0 AND UPR40600.SBJTSUTA=1) OR (UPR00400.SUTASTAT='' AND UPR40600.SBJTSUTA=1)

Christina Phillips, a Microsoft Certified Trainer and Dynamics GP Certified Professional, is a supervising consultant at BKD Technologies. She assists new and existing Microsoft Dynamics customers with training, support, and project management.

item.title: Exploring The Roycroft Campus in East Aurora, New York (Part 1)
item.description:
Dated: October 23, 2016

My wife Marlene and I recently got back from a two-day trip to Buffalo, New York, to meet up with some high school friends – Peggy, her husband Dick, and Ann. Peggy and Dick live in the Buffalo area and offered to take us sightseeing. Our main goal was to visit the Roycrofter Campus in East Aurora.

This picture shows the three women (I’ll always think of them as girls!) in the back seat of Dick’s car on Saturday morning. Marlene is on the left, then Ann, and then Peggy.

Our first stop was Our Lady of Victory Basilica in Lackawana. Here’s a photo from the parking lot…

This church is incredibly impressive architecturally – about as close as I’ll get to the Vatican. This is especially true considering Marlene and I attend a church in a renovated barn! Here’s an interior view…

The Basilica is enormous, and I remarked to Dick that it must be very expensive to heat. He informed me the church has its own natural gas well.

From the Basilica, we drove along Lake Erie on our way to Forest Lawn Cemetery, a popular tourist destination.

We were there to visit the grave of Millard Fillmore, the 13th US president. Fillmore was born in Moravia, New York – or technically nearby Summerhill, which is now essentially part of Moravia.

Marlene, Ann, Peggy, and I are all graduates of Moravia High School (class of 1976), and our social studies teacher was Bob Scarry, a Millard Fillmore expert who even wrote a book about him. Here’s a photo of the five of us at Fillmore’s grave…

We had a great time discussing history and trivia. At one point, Dick shared a piece of trivia I had never heard – Buddy Ebsen (Jed Clampett on The Beverly Hillbillies) was originally cast as the Tin Man in The Wizard of Oz, but he had an allergic reaction to the makeup. Here’s a picture of me and Dick from around that time…

As we walked back to the car, I told Marlene about what our classmate Ty St. John (who owns a memorial company) had told me at our reunion. He suggested taking pictures of headstones we like, which I thought was a great idea! Here’s one I really liked…

Later, we were all trying to remember all four members of The Monkees. We could only come up with Peter Tork, Davy Jones, and Michael Nesmith (whose mother invented Liquid Paper). Finally, Ann remembered the fourth Monkee - Mickey Dolenz, of course!

We had a 2:30 tour scheduled at the Roycroft campus, which gave us time for lunch at a coffee shop called Taste. I enjoyed a “Millard ‘Fill-Me-More’” wrap and a pumpkin spice latte.

During lunch, we discussed General Green, who lived in Moravia. Ann remembered him as a neighbor, and I knew about him from stories I had heard – including some from my mother, who helped care for his widow. Here’s a picture of General Green in his younger days…

General Green was at Pearl Harbor and even had an old car with bullet holes from the attack, which he would drive in parades. He was also involved in governing Hawaii while it was under martial law during the war.

After lunch, we visited Vidler’s 5 & 10 Store, an old-fashioned variety store. Marlene found a toy sheriff’s badge for our grandson, which we thought Dick might be able to use if he got pulled over!

We also drove past Millard Fillmore’s house in East Aurora, but we didn’t have time to stop. Fillmore was born in a log cabin, and a replica of it was built in Moravia with help from Bob Scarry. Here’s a picture of it…

(photo link)

Well, I’m out of space for now and haven’t even gotten to the Roycroft part of our trip! Stay tuned for Part 2…

item.title: Bay Area Beogram 8002: Initial Assessment
item.description:
This Beogram 8002 turntable, sent from California, is the next restoration project. I prefer working on the same type of audio equipment consecutively because it minimizes workbench setup time.

The owner followed our packing advice and packaged the turntable very well, using double boxes and protective foam. The turntable arrived without damage.

Upon opening, I noticed the metal tonearm lid wouldn’t stay up. The part that connects to the hinge with damping grease was detached, a problem I haven’t encountered before. The lid’s attachment to the hinge plate also appeared to be the original, surprisingly intact double-sided tape.

An initial electrical check showed the Beogram powered on and the platter turned when prompted. However, the tonearm wouldn’t move forward or backward during playback, and the Stop button didn’t return the arm. These are common issues I’ll address during restoration. I managed to return the arm to its resting position by tricking the sensor with a platter.

The tonearm compartment’s deck lid had deteriorated double-sided tape that will need replacing. The dustcover’s opening mechanism functioned correctly, but the back panel hinge assembly, although secure, raised concerns about potential damage during disassembly. To avoid this, I removed the dustcover and tonearm compartment lid by detaching the hinge bar. Interestingly, glue residue suggests prior repairs in this area.

I removed the transformer assembly and found a spider, a common occurrence in Bang & Olufsens! I proceeded to disassemble the Beogram into its service position for a complete assessment.

The internal components looked good, mostly original with only one capacitor appearing replaced. The usual areas, like the microcomputer box’s thermal grease, will be refreshed during restoration. The transformer compartment was fine, but the platter motor drive capacitor will be replaced, as will the two capacitors on the floating chassis.

I plan to check the scanning sensors and install a test connector for adjustments. The phono output board appeared fine, but I’ll replace the muting relay. The servo motor pulley was cracked and needs replacing. The tonearm wasn’t horizontally aligned – a problem for the service manual adjustments.

The subplatter (rotor) was unexpectedly glued to the hub with epoxy and required careful separation. I’ll use a removable adhesive when reassembling. The aluminum deck around the platter, while secure, was attached with a makeshift foam tape. I plan to replace it with VHB tape for a cleaner look.

Overall, this Beogram 8002 is in good condition. The electronic issues are typical and should be resolved by replacing capacitors, reflowing solder joints, and performing standard adjustments.

item.title: Shut Up That Screaming Cell Phone!
item.description:
A British company has developed a novel solution to combat the rising tide of cell phone theft: transforming stolen phones into sonic deterrents. The company, Synchronica, has introduced “wailing phones” that emit an earsplitting shriek when activated remotely. This piercing sound is designed to be so unsettling that it would make even the most hardened criminal think twice.

Synchronica’s system works in conjunction with their Mobile Manager service, which allows companies to remotely control their employees’ phones. If a device is stolen, authorized personnel can instantly lock it, erase all personal data, and activate the high-pitched alarm. This renders the stolen phone useless and forces the thief to discard it quickly.

Beyond the deterrent effect of the alarm, the system ensures data security. The moment the alarm is activated, any sensitive information stored on the phone is automatically deleted, preventing unauthorized access to contacts, emails, or private files.

The effectiveness of the screaming phone lies in its ability to attract immediate attention. A person holding a blaring phone becomes instantly conspicuous, making it difficult to blend in or profit from the stolen device. The sheer annoyance factor is enough to make anyone want to get rid of the phone as quickly as possible.

The article suggests that this technology could be applied to other security systems, such as car alarms. Imagine a world where car alarms, instead of emitting a monotonous beep, unleash a bloodcurdling scream. The author believes this would be far more effective in deterring theft and attracting attention.

The good news is that while Synchronica is based in the UK, they have a presence in the United States. This innovative security solution could soon be available to help protect against theft in the U.S.

item.title: Where, oh where did my budget disappear to?
item.description:
Nearing the end of the first quarter, many users begin adjusting their budgets and forecasts for the rest of the year. It’s common for users to accidentally delete or modify their budgets, so it’s important to review some guidelines for using budget windows in Microsoft Dynamics GP.

Let’s start with the Budget Maintenance window, accessed through Cards»Financial»Budget, then choosing either Open»Using Microsoft Dynamics GP or New»Using Microsoft Dynamics GP.

It’s crucial to remember that this window modifies the ENTIRE BUDGET unless a specific range is selected using the Ranges button. For example, clicking the Delete button removes the ENTIRE BUDGET. Similarly, using the Methods button to apply a 10% increase affects the ENTIRE BUDGET. This often surprises users who might manually adjust individual accounts within the window. However, buttons like Delete and Methods impact the entire budget unless a range restriction is in place.

To prevent mishaps, enable the Preliminary button BEFORE making any changes. This allows you to close the window and discard modifications if needed. Note that the discard option is unavailable if “actual” is marked; you can only Save or Delete. Remember, Delete impacts the ENTIRE BUDGET unless a range is specified using the Ranges button.

While this might sound intimidating, modifying budgets in Microsoft Dynamics GP doesn’t have to be frightening. Here are some helpful tips:

  • To change a single account, use the Single Account Budget Maintenance window, found at Cards»Financial»Account»Budget button. This window only affects the selected account’s budget and allows percentage-based adjustments.

  • After modifying your budget, create a backup by exporting it to Excel via Cards»Financial»Budget. This ensures easy recovery if any issues occur.

Feel free to share any budgeting tips and tricks you’ve learned while using Microsoft Dynamics GP. The upcoming GP2010 release will introduce exciting features, including the ability to enter transactions directly into a budget and combine multiple budgets. Until then, happy budgeting!

item.title: A delightful surprise from Holland, Massachusetts.
item.description:
Dated: September 4, 2016

Five years ago, I laid my mother and stepfather to rest in Holland, Massachusetts. I’ve previously written about the experience, including a tribute to my stepfather.

Pastor Bruce Plumley of the Holland Church officiated the service. We had never met before that day, and our interaction was brief. However, we did correspond through email, and I sent him a copy of my book, Writings of a Deliberate Agrarian.

Therefore, I was surprised a couple of weeks ago to receive an unexpected email from Pastor Plumley (shared here with his consent).

Good morning Herrick,

I know it has been many years and you may not remember me as vividly as I remember you.  I am the pastor at Holland Church in Holland Ma that conducted a graveside service for your family.  That day that we met, God blessed me with a treasure in you and your family that you will not realize this side of heaven.  This morning I had to let you know that your ministry has encouraged a weary pastor this day, and has caused me to fall on my knees and give our mighty God all glory and honor for His hand upon His people.

I have a copy of your book Writings of a Deliberate Agrarian.  I had this little book made into a hard copy so that it will last longer and it is beautifully well preserved.  I did this because of the blessing and value to me and I pray to many others as the years go by.  I do share this book and others have been likewise blessed.

Yesterday I was so overwhelmed with the battle against the enemy as I ministered to God’s people, that I pulled out your book and began to read yet again of “The Good Life”.  Now do not get me wrong this does not take the place of God’s Word, but this little book is solace to me and reminds me that life is good and can be better.

Thank you for sowing into my life with your wisdom and passions as God has gifted you.  I am a blessed man.

May God bless you abundantly in return,

Pastor Bruce Plumley

My biggest accomplishment in life is writing a book about building a Whizbang chicken plucker. I wrote it to make money, and it was successful enough to allow me to self-publish a book without profit as the goal.

Writings of a Deliberate Agrarian is a book I felt compelled to write, almost like a calling. Since its publication ten years ago, I’ve received a few letters similar to Pastor Plumley’s.

Such feedback is incredibly meaningful to me. Receiving a hundred positive comments from readers of my chicken plucker book doesn’t compare to the feeling of fulfillment I receive from one letter like his.

It’s fascinating to see how this book, and its deeper message, has resonated with some while leaving others indifferent. This is probably true for any book, but I’m more aware of it with this one.

For example, a few weeks ago, an older couple visited our church. When I introduced myself, the woman’s first response was, “I read your book.”

I suspected she was referring to Writings of a Deliberate Agrarian, but I was still taken aback. “How did you come across my book?” I asked.

“I found it at the thrift store,” she replied.

It turned out she worked at the local thrift store run by the Methodist Church. Someone I likely gifted the book to had donated it. It held little value for them, but remarkably, it was discovered and cherished by someone who did.

There’s an old William Cowper quote:

“God moves in mysterious ways, His wonders to perform.”

I witness this repeatedly in my life. The stories surrounding this book are just one example.

A Final Thought

Being a church pastor has to be one of the most challenging jobs imaginable.

Pastors face many disheartening realities, including worldly and apathetic churchgoers, a lack of love and biblical understanding, and a disregard for personal responsibility and striving for holiness.

I have immense respect and admiration for those who answer the call to pastor a church.

item.title: Get Your Employer to Pay For Your Broadband
item.description:
Companies may hesitate to increase employee benefits, but they become more receptive when these benefits also help their bottom line. Benefits that boost productivity and cut costs, such as providing free home broadband internet service, are more appealing to employers.

Although it sounds unbelievable, providing home broadband is a benefit some employers, including the U.S. government, are starting to offer. A news report revealed that the U.S. Patent and Trademark Office, with permission from the U.S. Government Accountability Office, can reimburse eligible employees for up to 100% of their home internet costs.

The catch is that this benefit is contingent on employees telecommuting from home up to four days a week and utilizing the internet for work purposes. Productivity will be monitored to ensure employees are genuinely working. Additionally, employees accepting this benefit must relinquish their office space at the Patent Office headquarters.

This arrangement benefits the company by freeing up valuable office space for other employees. While this opportunity might not appeal to executives, it could be highly advantageous for employees working in crowded office spaces. The company also benefits from broader organizational and societal advantages, such as reduced traffic congestion and pollution, as well as improved employee recruitment and retention due to the flexibility of working from home.

Employees also reap significant benefits from this arrangement, including cost savings on commuting, professional attire, meals, and potentially childcare. Plus, they enjoy the perk of free home broadband internet.

Telecommuting has long been a mutually beneficial arrangement for both employers and employees, especially in tech-savvy regions like Silicon Valley. Many companies nationwide have adopted flexible work arrangements, recognizing that allowing employees to work from home can be more cost-effective than investing in additional office space. With the government endorsing telecommuting, it might become a national strategy to tackle global warming and reduce reliance on foreign oil, all thanks to the small price of providing home broadband.

While this might seem like a minor perk, it’s a smart move by the government. Suburban commuting wastes significant time and energy and necessitates costly investments in expanding roadways to accommodate rush hour traffic. By setting a precedent for reimbursing home office broadband as a legitimate business expense, the government paves the way for companies to follow suit. Corporate savings on real estate, energy, office furniture, and supplies can easily outweigh the cost of providing internet service, especially given its declining price. Offering employees home broadband and perhaps even a company computer and software seems like a reasonable investment for companies, considering the potential cost savings they stand to gain.

item.title: Uh-Oh: Account Level Security and Advanced Search
item.description:
I’m continually surprised that even with a decade of training experience, Dynamics GP users still uncover unexpected features. Just recently, during a class, a situation arose concerning account level security and the advanced search within the account lookup window.

For those unfamiliar with account level security, sometimes called organizational structures, this Dynamics GP feature allows you to organize users and general ledger accounts according to your company’s structure. This limits which accounts each user can access. Companies use this for several reasons:

  • Preventing users from posting to the wrong accounts
  • Protecting sensitive account information from unauthorized viewing
  • Presenting a simplified interface showing only relevant accounts to each user

Let’s imagine a scenario where account level security is set up to display a limited list of accounts for payables clerks.

When they use the Accounts lookup, the first account shown is 000-6170-04. This is the first account in their restricted list, not the entire chart of accounts. This functions as intended, ensuring payables clerks only see their designated expense accounts. However, a question arises: what happens when a user utilizes the Advanced Search function?

In this example, using the Advanced Search (the binoculars icon) and searching for Account Numbers starting with “000-1” yields a list. Surprisingly, this list includes accounts that fit the criteria but fall outside the restricted access granted by account security. Attempting to select one of these accounts results in an error:

While you can see these accounts, you cannot use them without proper access. This presents a minor issue: although the list is secure for posting and reporting, it doesn’t prevent viewing account descriptions. These descriptions might contain sensitive data, like names, that some might assume are hidden from restricted users. However, this is not the case, so it’s crucial to plan accordingly.

A problem report exists for this issue, though it’s older and hasn’t gained much traction. Contact your Partner or Microsoft Support if you encounter this problem and want to be added to the list of affected customers. The report details are as follows:

MBS Great Plains 4799 - ‘Search Accounts’ returns all accounts, not just enabled

Have a great Thursday!

item.title: TXSHANTY and Tax Sheltered Deductions
item.description:
Coming back from vacation and jumping right into a busy week, I encountered a strange issue with a client’s FUTA and SUTA taxable wages in their system. Here’s the situation:

We had a deduction set up initially as non-tax-sheltered. Later, this was changed to be tax-sheltered with specific tax boxes checked. While the general setup reflected this change, the existing deduction records for employees did not automatically update to reflect the new tax-sheltered status.

Typically, this wouldn’t be a major problem as new employees would have the updated settings. However, the FUTA and SUTA reports were calculating wages incorrectly. These reports were configured to exclude tax-sheltered deductions, and in this case, the deductions shouldn’t have been excluded. Adjusting the FUTA and SUTA settings to include these deductions resolved the issue for employees without tax-sheltered flags but created a new problem for those who did.

After investigation, we found the culprit to be the TXSHANTY field in the UPR00500 table. This field, a boolean value, was set to 1 (meaning some tax-sheltered boxes were checked) even when all individual tax-sheltered checkboxes were actually unchecked. This discrepancy arose from a system quirk: while the system wouldn’t update the individual checkboxes due to existing activity, it was still updating the TXSHANTY field in the background. This essentially created an impossible situation where the main control flag indicated a tax-sheltered status even though no individual tax-sheltered options were selected.

To resolve this, we used SQL scripts to identify and correct the affected records by resetting the TXSHANTY field to 0 where it was erroneously set to 1. Following this correction, FUTA and SUTA calculations worked as expected based on the defined settings.

Interestingly, we also observed that the system seemed to be resetting the TXSHANTY field to 0 over time, although we couldn’t pinpoint the cause.

While Microsoft is in the process of documenting this as a bug, I wanted to share this experience in case others encounter a similar issue.

item.title: Ethernet over TDM
item.description:
You might be familiar with Ethernet over Copper and Ethernet over Fiber, but have you encountered Ethernet over TDM? It’s worth understanding this technology and its potential benefits.

](http://www.copperethernet.com/)

TDM, or Time Division Multiplexing, forms the foundation of T1 lines and SONET fiber optic services. It became the standard for the Public Switched Telephone Network (PSTN) during its transition from analog to digital in the mid-20th century and remains relevant due to its continued prevalence.

TDM enables the transmission of multiple signals over a single digital line or wireless channel by dividing the transmission into timeslots. Each timeslot carries digitized information for one signal, and these timeslots are grouped into a frame containing all the digital bits. This frame is sent from the source to the destination, followed by another frame, creating a continuous flow.

Imagine TDM as a round-robin process. Information chunks are collected from each source in turn. Once all sources are accounted for, the process restarts from the first source, ensuring a continuous stream of fresh data.

TDM allowed phone companies to combine 24 individual phone calls onto a single T1 line instead of requiring 24 separate wires. This multiplexing combines calls into a single bitstream transmitted over copper wires. At the receiving end, a demultiplexing process separates the calls for individual phones.

In contrast to TDM, Ethernet packages data into packets transmitted individually when ready. Instead of assembling packets into a multiplexed sequence, each packet is switched and routed independently.

While TDM circuits (like T1 lines) and packet-switched circuits (like Ethernet over Copper) are distinct technologies, innovative engineering allows one protocol to carry another. This is where Ethernet over TDM comes in.

Ethernet over TDM utilizes TDM as the underlying transmission protocol, often using a T1 line as an example. T1 frames transmit at 1.5 Mbps, and Ethernet packets are loaded into these frames. The usual practice of dividing the T1 line into 24 channels is bypassed, allowing Ethernet packets to utilize the entire frame. This maintains compatibility with existing T1 interfaces and signal regenerators.

Combining Ethernet and TDM offers flexibility. Ethernet over Copper faces distance limitations, performing well within a short range but experiencing signal degradation over longer distances. T1, on the other hand, offers greater distance coverage and consistent bandwidth, even in remote areas. Furthermore, the well-established nature of T1 lines makes them more widely available compared to the relatively newer Ethernet over Copper.

If you’re seeking the advantages of Ethernet, including bandwidth scalability, seamless network integration, and standardized services like Ethernet Line and Ethernet LAN, but lack access to Ethernet over Copper or Ethernet over Fiber, consider Ethernet over TDM. Also referred to as Ethernet over T1 or Ethernet over DS1, you can explore pricing and availability for Copper Ethernet Services.

item.title: Identifying errors in batches across all Dynamics GP company databases.
item.description:
A client encountered an issue where they needed to monitor batch errors across over 150 company databases in their system that utilizes Post Master Enterprise for automatic batch posting. While the automatic posting functions properly, occasional batch errors require a way to generate a comprehensive list of problematic batches across all databases.

Preliminary investigation suggests that the BCHSTTUS field in the SY00500 table, which indicates batch status, could be the key. A Microsoft KB article provides further details on the values for this field.

A SQL query focusing on this field was proposed as a starting point:

SELECT * FROM TWO..SY00500 WHERE BCHSTTUS > 6

However, this solution is not ideal for running across 150 databases.

To address this, a more complex SQL query utilizing a temporary table and a cursor was implemented. This query iterates through all company databases and populates the temporary table with the count of records with a batch status greater than 6.

While this approach works, it’s not certain if the batch status field is the sole indicator of batch recovery.

An alternative solution was suggested, leveraging a UNION ALL statement built dynamically through a join with sys.databases. This approach eliminates the need for a temporary table and a cursor, resulting in a more compact and efficient query.

item.title: Yes, user names in Dynamics GP are case sensitive.
item.description:
By Steve Endow

Customers occasionally report login issues with Dynamics GP, despite correctly entering their newly created user credentials.

If this happens, verify the capitalization of the GP user ID.

For example, using “testuser” to log in fails, as the accurate User ID is “TestUser”.

Unlike most software, Dynamics GP user IDs are case-sensitive. Therefore, always double-check the capitalization of user IDs if login problems occur.

item.title: Copper Bandwidth Connections Push 1 Gbps
item.description:
It seems impossible, but engineers continue to find ways to squeeze more speed out of traditional copper telephone lines, proving we haven’t reached the bandwidth limit yet. Imagine 1 Gbps speeds on copper lines for businesses!

While this technology isn’t widespread yet, it’s rapidly approaching. Huawei, a Chinese company specializing in networking and telecommunications, has developed a prototype Giga DSL system capable of delivering a combined speed of 1 Gbps within 100 meters of a remote terminal (RT) cabinet. The speed scales down to 500 Mbps at a distance of 200 meters.

This innovation follows Huawei’s SuperMIMO project, which utilizes four twisted copper pairs to achieve speeds of 700 Mbps over 400 meters. MIMO, short for Multiple Input Multiple Output, is the same antenna technology used in WiFi 802.3n to enhance range by employing multiple antennas for both transmission and reception. This technology combats multipath distortion, where radio waves interfere with each other. Using multiple antennas and intelligent system design, wave patterns are deciphered to reconstruct a clear signal.

But what does wireless transmission have to do with underground copper wires? Business telecommunications systems, such as multi-line phones, T1, and Ethernet over Copper, don’t use individual twisted pair lines. Instead, they are bundled together in binder cables containing 50 or more pairs. These twisted conductors effectively eliminate electromagnetic interference in low-speed transmissions like analog phone calls and dial-up internet. However, high-speed signals, such as EoC or T1, can leak into adjacent pairs within the cable, causing crosstalk interference. This is where MIMO technology comes in, mitigating interference between these wired paths, much like it addresses interference in wireless transmissions.

Other telecom equipment manufacturers are also making strides in this area. Alcatel-Lucent has developed DSL Phantom Mode, a technology that delivers 300 Mbps over two copper pairs, and 100 Mbps over distances up to 1 km. With its 1 km reach, this system is ideal for Ethernet over Copper in business districts and industrial parks.

The key to Alcatel-Lucent’s breakthrough is the “phantom circuit.” This technique, used in early wired communication, allowed for the transmission of additional telegraph signals or phone calls. Two phone lines, each using a twisted pair, could carry two separate calls. By connecting a circuit between them, a third call or telegraph signal could be transmitted. Transformers at each end of the lines, with the third circuit connected between their center taps, eliminate interference. This setup allows the “phantom circuit” to share the copper lines without disrupting the balanced lines.

Further enhancing bandwidth capacity, Alcatel-Lucent also employs bonded copper pairs. Additionally, they use VDSL2 vectoring to mitigate crosstalk between lines within a bundle. Similar to MIMO, vectoring utilizes digital signal processing to analyze and counteract interference effects on signals across copper pairs at the symbol level. This level of precision was impossible until recent advancements made high-speed DSP affordable. By applying complex mathematical algorithms to signal waveforms, it’s now possible to make incredibly precise adjustments, maximizing throughput for both wired and wireless transmissions.

But what’s driving this intense research into maximizing the potential of century-old copper connections? The answer lies in the exponential growth of bandwidth demand, driven by the increasing processing and storage requirements of big data. The shift from local data centers to the cloud further fuels the need for faster network lines for both WAN and LAN connections. While fiber optic technology is advancing and offering higher speeds, it’s only accessible to 75% of businesses at most. Plus, installation can be expensive and time-consuming. If existing copper infrastructure can be optimized to meet the growing need for bandwidth, businesses can quickly enhance their MAN and WAN network speeds using their current connections.

If your network is feeling the need for speed, both copper and fiber solutions are available today that were nonexistent just a short time ago. Explore current pricing and options for Ethernet over Copper and Fiber bandwidth to see what’s available in your area.

item.title: Difficulty in Dynamics GP when canceling accounts payable payments in a busy setting
item.description:
Steve Endow, a Microsoft MVP for Dynamics GP, frequently encounters unusual issues in his work. Recently, while working with a large Dynamics GP customer that processes thousands of international AP payments each month, he discovered a challenging problem. This company often experiences unsuccessful payment deliveries due to various reasons like incorrect payment information. The high volume of failed payments requires them to void and reissue hundreds of payments monthly in Dynamics GP, a very time-consuming process.

To address this, Steve developed an automated solution to void payments in GP. During testing, he encountered a scenario where the same check or payment number was issued from multiple checkbooks in Dynamics GP. This meant a vendor could receive two payments with the same check number but from different checkbooks.

The Void Historical Payables Transactions window in Dynamics GP doesn’t readily display the checkbook ID, making it difficult to determine which payment to void automatically. A manual user could investigate each payment individually, but an automated solution requires additional logic.

This situation highlights that even seemingly improbable scenarios can occur in ERP systems, particularly with flexible functionalities like in Dynamics GP. Consequently, custom solutions become necessary to handle these unique situations, even if they seem unlikely.

item.title: 2x2 Ethernet Takes on T-1
item.description:
For the past decade, small and medium businesses have relied on T1 lines as their primary commercial telecom solution. However, a new competitor called 2x2 Ethernet, recently introduced by major nationwide carrier MegaPath, is emerging to challenge the long-standing T1. Let’s explore what 2x2 Ethernet offers.

It might seem surprising that T1 lines would face competition, considering their 50-year history and widespread adoption. As the first widely available broadband digital connection for businesses, T1 emerged from telephone company research. Initially used to connect calls between switching centers, it later became commercially available. Leveraging repeater technology and unshielded twisted pair telco wires, T1 became the leading technology for digital phone lines, point-to-point connections, and dedicated broadband access.

Ethernet, on the other hand, originated in the computer industry and has become the dominant networking technology for local area networks (LANs). While traditionally considered a LAN technology, unlike the WAN-focused T1, Ethernet has steadily expanded into metropolitan and wide area networks in recent years. Now, it’s poised to replace T1 lines altogether. But why?

Bandwidth is a key factor. T1 lines offer a fixed, symmetrical bandwidth of 1.5 Mbps for both uploads and downloads. Ethernet, however, supports various speeds over copper and fiber optic cables. MegaPath’s 2x2 Ethernet provides 2 Mbps for both uploads and downloads, a modest but notable improvement over T1. Beyond the 33% capacity increase, 2x2 Ethernet offers simple integration. Connecting from WAN to LAN is as easy as using a standard Ethernet connector, eliminating the need for additional CSU/DSU interface circuitry required by T1 lines.

The most compelling aspect of MegaPath’s 2x2 Ethernet is its affordability compared to T1 lines. While Ethernet has often boasted lower per-Mbps costs than traditional telecom services, particularly at higher bandwidths, this 2 Mbps service undercuts the price of a 1.5 Mbps service. Additionally, customers can choose between data-only or voice and data configurations. Opting for at least five lines of digital, analog, or SIP trunking telephone service further reduces the cost of a 2x2 Ethernet line. These factors suggest that the era of T1 dominance might be coming to an end.

MegaPath has addressed availability concerns by offering Ethernet over Copper connections through 1,900 central offices across the country, covering an estimated 90% of businesses, both small and large. MegaPath itself is a “super CLEC” (Competitive Local Exchange Carrier), formed by merging MegaPath, Covad, and Speakeasy, all significant carriers in their own right.

If your business needs new connectivity or you’re simply seeking a better deal on your current T1 line service, it’s worth exploring your options. Older T1 contracts could be costing you double what they should. Consider a quick pricing and availability inquiry for Ethernet over Copper services to be sure. Higher bandwidth options are also available for more demanding applications.

item.title: WiMAX 4G Wireless is Off and Running With Sprint Nextel
item.description:
With the emergence of 3G cellular broadband using technologies like EV-DO and HSDPA, Sprint Nextel is taking the lead by introducing the first 4G wireless broadband network in the U.S., utilizing WiMAX technology.

Several factors have converged to make this the opportune moment for nationwide WiMAX broadband, with Sprint being the ideal company to spearhead it. WiMAX is reaching maturity, with numerous trial deployments, solidified standards, and certified equipment being manufactured at scale. WiMAX’s global dominance has been evident, with the only question being the timing of its widespread adoption. It seems mid-2006 marks a significant milestone, with services slated to commence by the end of the following year.

Sprint is committed to deploying the IEEE802.16e-2005 Mobile WiMAX standard due to its adaptability for both fixed and mobile data transfers.

Sprint and Nextel are primarily known as cell phone providers, and their immediate application for WiMAX is to enhance existing services such as SprintTV video on demand, music downloads, and other 3G entertainment options. Sprint intends to deploy its 4G WiMAX network alongside its 3G EV-DO network, with Motorola and Samsung manufacturing devices compatible with both. Similar to current 3G devices that transition between speeds depending on coverage, the new networks will fall back from WiMAX to EV-DO outside metropolitan WiMAX deployment areas.

Beyond enhancing video downloads, WiMAX offers significant potential. Its design as a wireless Metropolitan Area Network (MAN) enables broadband internet service delivery to laptops and desktops, covering up to 31 miles with shared bandwidth up to 70 Mbps. Sprint is projected to deliver 2 to 4 Mbps bandwidth to fixed and mobile users, a substantial improvement over 3G speeds. This makes WiMAX an attractive alternative to DSL and cable broadband, especially with Intel’s plan to incorporate WiMAX solutions into its Centrino Mobile Technology devices. Consequently, we can anticipate the emergence of devices with built-in WiMAX alongside WiFi, including wireless access points and routers equipped with a WiMAX transceiver for WAN and WiFi for LAN.

Furthermore, Sprint and Nextel can leverage WiMAX technology to backhaul their cellular phone traffic. Currently, many cell towers rely on T1 landlines with limited bandwidth. Implementing WiMAX on towers for customer broadband service presents an opportunity to replace these lines with long-range radio carriers, creating a system upgrade and potentially reducing costs.

Another factor contributing to Sprint’s decision is the need to utilize their extensive 2.5 GHz band licenses effectively. Both Sprint and Nextel hold significant licenses in this former MMDS band, covering over 85% of households in the top 100 U.S. markets. This valuable spectrum is currently underutilized. Moreover, Sprint Nextel is obligated to establish a 2.5 GHz network reaching at least 30 million people by the end of the decade as part of their merger agreement with the FCC. Sprint Nextel aims to surpass this commitment, targeting 100 million people by the end of 2008.

Sprint Nextel possesses a valuable asset in their 2.5 GHz band, highly suitable for WiMAX transmissions. These frequencies penetrate buildings more effectively than the 3.5 GHz and 5.8 GHz bands, also designated for WiMAX. This presents an opportunity to replace wireline broadband services and enable practical indoor and in-vehicle roaming. Eventually, WiFi hotspots may become obsolete, similar to dial-up internet service.

A nationwide WiMAX network will likely foster the development of innovative business and consumer mobile services that demand greater bandwidth. This includes applications like full-motion video conferencing, streaming audio and video, large database applications, and mobile simulations and presentations. The prospect of widespread WiMAX might even prompt faster deployment of fiber optic networks and further innovation in mobile applications.

item.title: Buy Convergence By The Byte
item.description:
XO Communications is revolutionizing telecommunications by offering IP Network services priced by bandwidth usage instead of traditional lines or channels. This shift to an IP-based network and the use of Session Initiation Protocol (SIP) for telephone trunking are rendering traditional telephony services obsolete. By utilizing a packet-switched network and transmitting everything in packet protocol, voice, and data traffic can easily share a single circuit.

The concept of convergence, using one network for voice, video, and data, has gained traction with IT departments aiming to simplify network management and executives seeking cost reductions. However, the disparity between local area networks and wide area network services has posed a challenge. The need for protocol conversion and call termination to bridge the gap between IP inside the organization and TDM outside has been a significant obstacle.

XO’s IPfolio changes this paradigm in two key ways. Firstly, its suite of IP services runs on a single network, allowing businesses to create customized solutions by seamlessly mixing and matching services. This “telecom buffet” offers options like IP VPNs, SIP-based telephone trunking, and dedicated internet access with dynamic bandwidth allocation. Voice is treated as a data application, which is key to achieving network convergence.

Secondly, and more disruptively, IPfolio pricing is based on Mbps used, not by feature, bundle, or service. With bandwidth options from 1.5 to 45 Mbps, businesses get unlimited local and inter-site calls. This SIP-based VoIP telephony eliminates channel or “line” limitations – enabling as many simultaneous calls as the bandwidth allows. The service is compatible with major PBX systems like Cisco and Avaya. Optional long-distance plans ranging from 2,000 to 40,000 minutes per month are also available.

The XO MPLS IP-VPN, part of IPfolio, provides a secure MPLS network solution with VPN capabilities to connect multiple business locations. Its multiple service classes ensure smooth application performance and prevent large data downloads from disrupting real-time voice communication.

XO IPfolio aims to provide a comprehensive suite of communication services with IP-based pricing. Introduced in 2007 in select cities, IPfolio is now available nationwide.

item.title: Gigabit WiFi For Video Streaming
item.description:
WiFi has become the standard wireless connection due to its widespread availability, outpacing technologies like Bluetooth and WiMax. While cellular data is useful in the absence of WiFi, its limited bandwidth and potential for overage charges make it a secondary choice. In fact, data shows that most tablet users don’t even utilize their device’s cellular capabilities. WiFi’s strength is evident in its ability to not only replace cellular broadband but also wired connections.

Setting up Ethernet cables in homes and offices is a challenge for many, leading to a reliance on strategically placed WiFi routers to provide internet access throughout a space. The convenience of WiFi is further amplified by the increasing availability of WiFi-enabled PCs and printers, offering users greater flexibility in device placement.

However, the limitations of physical cables persist in video transmission, with traditional coaxial and HDMI cables being necessary for connecting devices. While older coaxial cables are restricted to standard-definition video, even the higher-quality HDMI cables pose a challenge in terms of installation and reach within a home.

Adding to the complexity is the convergence of traditional video sources like satellite and DVDs with internet-based content. Now, televisions, Blu-ray players, and gaming consoles often come equipped with Ethernet ports, primarily for streaming high-bandwidth video content. This begs the question: can a wireless solution effectively replace these wired connections for video transmission?

While earlier WiFi standards like 802.11b/g fall short of the requirements for seamless video streaming, the newer 802.11n standard, though improved, still faces challenges with bandwidth and interference in the crowded 2.4 GHz frequency band. This is where the enhanced WiFi 802.11ac, or “WiFi-AC,” comes in.

What sets WiFi-AC apart is its significant increase in bandwidth, exceeding one gigabit per second. With a projected capacity of nearly seven gigabytes per second for an eight-antenna system, WiFi-AC is poised to handle the demands of high-definition and 3D video streaming, potentially eliminating the need for Ethernet, HDMI, and coaxial cables in both homes and offices.

This performance leap in WiFi-AC is achieved by utilizing the less congested 5 GHz frequency band and employing wider transmission channels. Unlike 802.11n’s 40 MHz channels, WiFi-AC utilizes a minimum of 80 MHz channels, expandable up to 160 MHz, allowing for greater data transfer rates.

WiFi-N introduced MIMO (Multiple Input Multiple Output) antenna technology, which improves signal quality and strength by analyzing multiple received signals and filtering out interference. WiFi-AC leverages this technology and enhances it with a more sophisticated modulation scheme known as 256 QAM (Quadrature Amplitude Modulation). This allows for more efficient use of the spectrum, translating to higher data rates compared to the 64 QAM used in 802.11n.

With Broadcom’s recent announcement of the first 802.11ac supporting chipset, which they are calling “5G WiFi,” consumers can anticipate seeing WiFi-AC equipped devices in the market by late this year or early next year. This new generation of WiFi technology is set to bring significant performance improvements, similar to the generational leaps witnessed in cellular technology (2G, 3G, 4G).

item.title: Try Internet Fax For Free
item.description:
Even though constantly texting is the norm today, fax machines are still important, especially in business, where they’re used for contracts and other key documents. But that doesn’t mean you need a bunch of fax machines in your office. You can send and receive faxes online, wherever you are, with the right fax plan.

Instead of a clunky fax machine, a fax service plan is much more practical. Fax machines can only send faxes and take up space, while a fax service plan lets you send and receive faxes digitally through email and an online account, using your computer or laptop.

You might remember older fax software that needed a special modem and monopolized your computer and phone line. Modern fax services are totally different. You don’t need a fax modem or even a phone line because it works entirely online, just like other internet-based applications.

Signing up for an internet fax service plan like RingCentral, or even trying their free trial, gives you a dedicated toll-free or local fax number. This virtual fax number allows other fax machines to send faxes directly to your online account, and you’ll receive them as emails. You can even get notifications about new faxes on your phone, so you won’t miss anything urgent.

Sending faxes is also easy. You can send a fax straight from your email, with your email becoming the cover sheet and any attached documents becoming the fax itself. There’s also free software that adds a fax button to programs like Microsoft Word and Outlook, letting you fax documents with a single click. You can even use a digital version of your signature, so no printing, signing, or scanning is needed.

An internet fax service is just as powerful as a traditional fax machine. You can create groups to send faxes to multiple people at once, all without tying up a phone line. The system will even notify you when your faxes are delivered. You can customize cover sheets and choose from various page styles using either the software or the online account. You can also block junk faxes to keep your inbox clean.

The best part is that you don’t even need your computer to be on to receive faxes, and senders will never get a busy signal. It’s all online!

Best of all, these plans are affordable, starting at $7.99 per month for 300 pages, with a small fee for additional pages. If you send a lot of faxes, there are plans for up to 2,500 pages each month. And that price includes your dedicated fax number, which could cost as much as the entire plan from other providers.

item.title: Who Wants A Computer In Their Car?
item.description:
Ford is considering adding in-dash computers to their work trucks and vans, which begs the question: could passenger cars be next? This technology would replace laptops that contractors currently rely on, offering features like digital forms, planning documents, and even invoice printing.

While this is helpful for construction workers, an in-dash computer could benefit others, too. Salespeople, consultants, and anyone who conducts business on-the-go could manage messages, documents, orders, receipts, and faxes directly from their vehicles.

Though laptops already offer these capabilities, an in-dash computer could integrate with a car’s existing systems. For example, by connecting a general-purpose PC to the navigation system and incorporating broadband internet access, we could access real-time features like weather radar superimposed onto the map.

Furthermore, this technology could replace traditional radios by streaming online services like Pandora through a robust broadband connection, potentially outperforming satellite and over-the-air radio. Local content might then become more unique and valuable.

With wireless internet and a printer, GPS systems could expand to provide full website access for restaurants, stores, services, and tourist spots, allowing users to purchase tickets or order ahead.

Naturally, driver distraction is a concern. However, passengers could utilize the in-dash computer safely, with potential for remote screens, game controls, and keyboards in the backseat. This could transform travel into an interactive experience with educational games or scavenger hunts.

Combined with hands-free calling and video conferencing, the in-dash computer could become a comprehensive communication hub. The possibilities seem endless when you have the power of a PC with broadband internet access directly within your dashboard.

item.title: Your Next Battery Is a Capacitor
item.description:
Benjamin Franklin’s experiment with capturing electricity in Leyden Jars, glass jars with foil conductors that store electric charge, laid the groundwork for modern battery technology.

Today, researchers have developed ultracapacitors, like the Graphene Ultracapacitor from the University of Texas at Austin, which are essentially very small but powerful capacitors. These ultracapacitors use nanometer-thin dielectrics instead of bulky glass jars, allowing them to achieve farad-level capacitance, much higher than the picofarad capacity of a Leyden Jar.

This increased capacity means ultracapacitors can act more like batteries, able to power devices for longer periods than traditional capacitors. While capacitors could only deliver a brief jolt of electricity, often used for pranks in electronics classes, ultracapacitors have the potential to power devices like cell phones. The author recounts a memorable incident where a student mistakenly connected an electrolytic capacitor to a wall outlet, resulting in a small explosion. Thankfully, capacitors at that time were not as powerful as modern ultracapacitors.

Both capacitors and batteries can act as power sources, but capacitors have the advantage of charging rapidly. Although limited by their size in storing a significant amount of power, advancements in material science like graphene are paving the way for ultracapacitors to potentially power everything from cell phones and computers to watches and even hybrid vehicles, much like high-tech versions of Leyden Jars.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Keypad and RPM Panel
item.description:
Slow response times from the Beogram’s control panel buttons pointed to potential oxidation on the keypad contacts. This was confirmed upon opening the keypad assembly, revealing dull key contacts.

The contact pads were unsoldered and removed for a closer look. While they seemed okay, the leaf contacts engaged by the actuators showed signs of oxidation.

To address the oxidation, a fiberglass brush and Deoxit were used, restoring the contacts to a shiny and clean condition.

The next electrical task involved replacing the RPM indicator lamps. This was crucial as LED replacements had proven to improve platter motor stability during testing. It’s important to note that the RPM indicator lamps are integral to the platter motor’s control circuit, and each speed indicator has a dedicated pitch (speed) adjustment knob.

Pictured below is the RPM indicator module with its original incandescent lamps.

And here’s the RPM indicator with the Beolover lamp replacement modules installed.

These Beolover modules are designed for compatibility with the pitch control circuit. Their SMD LEDs are calibrated to blend light colors, mimicking the original incandescent lamps.

The images below showcase the 33 and 45 RPM speeds illuminated by the new light modules. All control panel buttons now exhibit immediate responsiveness upon pressing.

With all Beogram functions now operational, the next stage involves meticulous checking and adjustment in line with the service manual’s guidelines. Once these adjustments are finalized and all checks are successfully passed, it will be time to enjoy the pleasure of vinyl playback once more.

item.title: Bandwidth Windfall
item.description:
When budgets are strained, expanding into new markets and generating much-needed revenue often depends on increasing Wide Area Network (WAN) bandwidth. However, more bandwidth usually means higher expenses, creating a difficult situation.

It’s generally accepted that increasing bandwidth leads to increased costs. For instance, 10 Mbps will likely cost more than 1 Mbps, although there might be a volume discount. But is it possible to get more bandwidth while paying less overall? This idea seems counterintuitive.

Telecom pricing traditionally wouldn’t support this idea, but there are two ways to achieve more bandwidth at a lower cost, particularly with dedicated internet connections and point-to-point private lines.

The first approach involves moving your operations to a colocation facility, also known as a carrier hotel. These facilities house equipment from multiple carriers, making bandwidth readily available. You can lease space for your servers and connect to the desired bandwidth with minimal construction costs.

The second approach is Metro Ethernet or Carrier Ethernet. These services provide Ethernet speeds ranging from 10 Mbps to 1000 Mbps at competitive rates. While higher bandwidth levels typically require fiber optic connections, lower speeds can sometimes utilize existing copper wiring.

Remarkably, 100 Mbps Fast Ethernet service often costs less than traditional 45 Mbps DS3 bandwidth. This means you can double your speed for less money, offering a significant advantage for businesses seeking growth.

item.title: What is an Ethernet Connection?
item.description:
When we consider connecting to the wider world, traditional telecom services like POTS, PRI, T1, DS3, and OCx SONET often come to mind. However, Carrier Ethernet, a newer technology that extends Ethernet from the LAN to the WAN, is worth examining.

Extending an Ethernet connection from a building or campus to a distant location might seem strange considering traditional telecom’s long-standing dominance. However, the landscape is changing with new providers entering the market, unburdened by legacy telco standards. This allows for a fresh perspective on WAN design, pricing, and services.

For this discussion, let’s assume the WAN starts where the LAN ends, acknowledging that the MAN, or Metropolitan Area Network, often sits between them. While MAN and WAN technologies are similar, differing mainly in scale, WAN services can span regional, national, or even international boundaries, unlike MANs which typically cover a city and its surrounding areas.

Ethernet, the dominant packet switching protocol for LANs, wasn’t always so widespread. Decades ago, standards like Token Ring competed for dominance. However, Ethernet’s popularity and cost-effectiveness have solidified its position in the LAN market. While only recently gaining traction in the WAN space, Ethernet may very well replicate its success in the local and metropolitan network environments in the coming years.

Thanks to the Metro Ethernet Forum (MEF)’s standardization efforts, Carrier Ethernet overcomes the distance limitations of traditional LAN Ethernet, enabling connections that span the globe. By standardizing Ethernet services, the MEF ensures interoperability between different carriers, fostering competition and driving down costs for consumers. This standardization also allows carriers to expand their reach by interconnecting through Ethernet Network to Network Interfaces (E-NNI).

WAN Ethernet offers several advantages over legacy telecom services. Firstly, the interface is much simpler: unlike T1 or DS3 connections requiring specialized equipment, an Ethernet connection can be established using a standard RJ-45 jack or a managed router.

Secondly, Ethernet offers flexible service options. Ethernet Line Service provides point-to-point or last-mile dedicated Internet connections, similar to T1 or DS3. Ethernet LAN service, on the other hand, offers multipoint networking, connecting multiple business locations without the need for individual private lines.

Unlike T-Carrier and SONET services, Ethernet is highly scalable. Bandwidth can be adjusted easily, often with a simple phone call to the provider, eliminating the need for equipment replacement and downtime.

Finally, Ethernet WAN connections offer cost benefits, often providing double the bandwidth for the price of a T1 line. These savings become even more substantial at higher speeds.

It’s worth comparing Ethernet WAN services and pricing with your current setup to determine if you are missing out on potential cost and performance advantages. Ethernet WAN is available over both twisted pair copper and fiber optic cabling.

item.title: Confirmed: A bug that has been present for 8 years has been found in the eConnect Requester SOP Transaction trigger.
item.description:
In a recent blog post, I discussed an issue with eConnect Requester’s inability to accurately capture newly added Sales Order Processing (SOP) transactions.

While a temporary solution was found for a specific task, the same problem resurfaced during the next phase of the project, halting progress.

Determined to find a permanent fix, I investigated the eConnect Requester SOP10100 Insert Trigger. My findings revealed a significant bug, likely present for at least eight years across various GP versions, including 2015, 2013, and 2010. Surprisingly, this bug seems to have gone unnoticed or unaddressed for several years, with users likely finding workarounds without questioning the root cause.

Unfortunately, I’m currently tasked with untangling a decade-old integration heavily reliant on the Requester (using MSMQ, no less). To proceed, I must find a way to overcome this bug.

Let’s examine the trigger’s logic and understand why the Sales Transaction Insert trigger fails.

When enabling the Sales_Transaction “SO_Trans” Insert Trigger, eConnect Requester generates a trigger on the SOP10100 table. This trigger includes a substantial amount of SQL code that uses a cursor to iterate through inserted records, giving the impression of functionality. However, entering an SOP transaction in Dynamics GP results in an empty eConnect_Out table, indicating a problem.

Investigating further with SQL Server Profiler reveals that the trigger activates and the cursor fetches data, but the eConnect_Out table remains empty. This suggests a condition in the trigger script is preventing the SOP record from being processed.

The issue lies in the fact that an Insert trigger on the SOP10100 table doesn’t capture records when an SOP transaction is saved. This is because Dynamics GP utilizes placeholder records in the SOP10100 table.

When initiating an SOP transaction in GP, a placeholder record with blank values is inserted into the SOP10100 table as soon as the Document Number (SOPNUMBE) appears in the Sales Transaction Entry window. This placeholder record is only updated upon saving the transaction, populating fields like the customer number. Notably, the Dex Row ID remains unchanged, confirming an update operation, not a deletion followed by an insertion.

The SO_Trans trigger’s logic hinges on the presence of a Customer Number (CUSTNMBR) to write the transaction to the eConnect_Out table. Since the placeholder record initially lacks this value, the trigger doesn’t execute the intended action.

Therefore, due to the placeholder system in SOP10100 and the trigger’s design, the eConnect Requester SOP10100 Insert trigger remains ineffective, never populating the eConnect_Out table.

What alternatives exist for those facing this challenge?

One option is to utilize the eConnect Requester Sales_Transaction Line trigger instead. This can provide notification of a new Sales Transaction, depending on the specific requirements.

While the eConnect Requester Update trigger for SOP10100 might seem viable, it presents complications. Every update to an existing SOP transaction would populate the eConnect_Out table, requiring additional filtering to isolate relevant entries.

As a next step, I plan to test the Line trigger on SOP10200, hoping it offers a suitable workaround without unexpected side effects.
